review_title: Friendly and flexible culture, noncompetitive salaries, lukewarm benefits
pros: My department is very flexible with personal time -- it is never a problem for me to have an appointment in the middle of the day that may take longer than an hour, or for me to come in late or leave early because of an appointment or family-related circumstance. They don't nickel and dime me for time and I appreciate that. In my department, we have the resources to execute the projects I want. I just have to jump through hoops to get approvals.
cons:
As much as they tout great benefits -- they're pretty awful. For a family, the PPO/POS plans are very expensive. The HMO plan is more reasonable but comes with high co-pays for everything as well as the hoops you have to jump through to see the doctors and specialists you need to. Their maternity leave policy is also ungenerous, and you are forbidden from taking any personal time off unless it is concurrent with your FMLA time -- so new moms will in most cases never get more than 12 weeks off for maternity leave.

Very bureaucratic although I suspect that varies from unit to unit.

Salaries are low, low, low. I had to take a $10,000 pay cut when I got here. Still not making what I was making seven years ago at my previous employer (also a large research university). From what I can tell, very few people here are paid fairly in accordance with the Philadelphia market.

review_title: Psychology Research Assistant at the University of Pennsylvania
pros: One of the best reasons to work for the University of Pennsylvania is its reputation, which is known far and wide. Additionally, at the University of Pennsylvania there are abundant opportunities to network within the university and to work with and learn from well-known academics. I was also very satisfied with the benefits package; in particular, the generous vacation time offered. The University of  Pennsylvania's campus is a fun place to work, with plenty of interesting places to eat lunch and fun places to kill free time. Additionally, the University of Pennsylvania is easily accessible by public transportation (train, bus or trolley).
cons: One of the main downsides of working at the University of Pennsylvania, to me, was the expense and hassle of commuting into University City as opposed to other worksites where on-site parking is available (paid parking may be available as a perk of higher level jobs but it was not available to me as a lowly Research Assistant). Another downside of working at the University of Pennsylvania was the low salary compared to other settings (e.g., private industry) - it appears that they realize that it is a great experience and there is a high demand for positions there, so they are able to get away with paying less. Additionally, there was a great deal of backbiting within those departments that I was exposed to (psychology/psychiatry).

pros: Penn is a l first class place to work, as far as universities are concerned.  They have excellent networking  and professional development opportunities, as well as  fantastic departmental support for faculty and staff. The campus is beautiful, and the student population is entrepreneurial, creative, and as a whole, fantastic. Of course, there are a few bad apples, but people are generally motivated and  hard working. Keep in mind it is part of the Ivy league, so standards are high.  If you do well, it is a gratifying experience.
cons:
The environment at Penn tends to be very 'type A.' That makes work and life balance very challenging, as people are perfectionists. It is easy to get overworked. Also,  there can be a lot of competitiveness, which can be good and bad.  

Special note for non-tenured faculty members:  Beware of low  pay for faculty members without tenure... especially part-time employees. If  you are looking to work in academia, it has many great opportunities.  However, let the reader understand, non-tenure track faculty are generally treated like second-class citizens..even less than the staff.  In other words, it is expected that your contract will be shorter, and any departmental change may put your job in jeopardy.   Also, non-tenure faculty generally have to share working spaces with many others.

pros: great team, great benefits, good pay

review_title: Wonderful academic environment except if you are a Postdoctoral Fellow
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Immersive Academic Environment, Collegial, Lots of research resources
cons:
If you are a postdoctoral fellow then you are probably pushing late-20s maybe 30, but UPENN won't enroll you in their 403b (equivalent to the 401k retirement plan), nor will they offer matching contributions to any retirement planning.  Every other employee from 18 year old janitors up to the university president will have this option though,~ but not if you have a Ph.D.~ if you are 30 and have never been offered a retirement plan by an employer then I'm sure you don't have to expect to be offered one now.  

Even better, postdoctoral fellows don't have federal taxes withheld from their pay at all.  Postdoctoral fellows still have to pay the taxes themselves every quarter or will face late fees when filing taxes.  Who needs to do experiments when you can spend one evening every three months  blundering around on the U.S. government's horribly made self-pay tax website?  Luckily your trainee status exempts you from social security and medicare tax liability.  I guess the payroll/accounting department at Penn and the millions paid in salaries to employees in that department can't really handle that there are some employees that have to have their tax withholding handled differently.  Unlike other universities, you will have to do it yourself at UPenn.

Like most educational environments, expect to do complete paperwork in triplicate before even getting the opportunity to perform your actual job. And there's never any parking.

job_title: Building Operations Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The Benefit package includes a very good tuition scholarship program which helps up front with putting your kids through college. They also offer some percentage based pre-tax expenses such as medical benefits, public transportation costs and additional insurance costs. (ie: family coverage is paid for by employee but a portion of it is charged pre-tax)
cons: The University seems tp promote a very political environment, the lack of experience presented by upper management related to the specific areas that they control causes friction within the departments, there are not many advancement oppurtunities because current employees tend to have been there a long time and are looking to last until retirement, the salary for lower level management is slightly below average but the most disapponting fact is the lack of  bonus' or incentives for good performance. Raises are based on a tier system with upper management controlling and keeping as much as possible for themselves. This consistently leads to below cost of living increases which makes it difficult to financially survive year after year not alone never having an oppurtunity to get ahead.

review_title: Hit or Miss. Choose your department wisely.
pros: If you find yourself in one of the good environments, people are amazing, benefits are extremely generous and pay is very good (for a university position). It's a fantastic place to work if you value your work/life balance. If you get a bad vibe during your interviews, be wary.
cons: Super decentralized. Workplaces can vary GREATLY from department to department. Poor managers are often promoted out of positions rather than fired. It's amazing what I've seen people get away with. Nepotism out the wazoo. The most political place I've ever worked. It truly is who you know rather than what you know that will get you places here.

job_title: Clinical Research Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Great work life balance - 9 to 5 easy to pull off), 
Benefits - Great medical, dental, vision, and tuition benefits, with extra & various perks here and there 
Good job security - It's very hard to be laid off or get fired unless there's something seriously wrong with you, very stable 
Good for transitional employees - If you want some time off of school before you go for an advanced degree, this is a good place to work with a lot of flexibility
cons:
Low pay - My lab paid the absolute minimum allowed, with yearly increases barely consistent with inflation.  While livable, it was quite the pittance for someone with a bachelor's degree.
Low career growth - Promotions never seemed to happen unless someone quit; I wouldn't count on making a career here.  Make sure you have something to look forward to.
Boring - After a while, the work became a set of routines that were hard to break out of, especially when a promotion isn't on the table.  Frequently discouraging.

review_title: Excellent overall, but your mileage may vary.
pros:
Penn has a friendly, inclusive atmosphere.
The employee benefits are seriously outstanding. They even include tuition at Penn, and assistance with purchasing a home in West Philadelphia.
The work is satisfying and respectful of a healthy work/life balance. It feels like they really do invest in your well being as a whole. My life is substantially better than before I worked at Penn.
cons:
Penn is a BIG place. While it's true that you technically work for the University as a whole, your experience at work will depend more on *where* you work. There are many different sub-entities based on school and/or type of work, with each being independently managed. Some places will be better managed than others, and some will have more competitive salaries than others. Such is life in a huge research university.

It's near impossible to get fired, at least where I work. It takes committing an actual crime to get the boot. In some ways, it's nice to know you've got job security, but if you're unlucky, it can also mean being permanently stuck under incompetent management. When things need to change, it can be hard to instigate that change.

review_title: Wonderful Ivy League to attend to
pros: To best describe the research scenario in University of Pennsylvania is like tasting a drop of the ocean. With its ancient history of education rooted by William Penn and dreamers like Benjamin Franklin to inventing computers in 1800's ..Penn is all set to be awarded gold in red and blue for its academic excellence and vitality in bringing the innate desire or passion of every young scientist aspiring to become Einsteins
cons: Well the security is always beefed up and no visitor is allowed any premises..even it happens to an Alumni (of course to who doesn't own a Rolls Royce or Mercedes). Second thing is some professors have grown so tough (thanks to the environment) that they  don't even talk to people at some instances. Fees are way up high and only very few eligible candidates can afford that much..

pros: Penn has great benefits in terms of paid time off and retirement.  In addition, Penn employees can take up to 2 classes per term for free.  Employees are often encouraged to use these classes to explore interests or gain expertise in their field.  It's relatively easy to move around within the university, so you can move to a completely different department with a much less stressful job search.
cons: Salaries at Penn are significantly lower than they are at other employers.  The system by which HR determines salary offers leaves no room for negotiation.  HR also limits raises;  the average raise for a department cannot exceed 3.5%, and the maximum raise for an individual is 5%.  As a result, it is pretty much impossible to be paid anywhere near what you'd get elsewhere.

review_title: Great benefits and atmosphere make up for non-profit pay
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great benefits, lots of vacation time, same sex spousal benefits, tuition benefits are top notch (if you can get into the University), week long holiday break for all university employees, lenient dress code. Some departments can be flexible with the hours you work (especially for taking classes during the work day). Housing benefits
cons: Pay is lower than one may expect (especially for grant funded research). Classified as a CRC even though it was a technical position. Always tons of construction going on. Mingling amongst some disrespectful college students. Surprising lack of affordable and good places to eat. Housing benefits aren't what they used to be.

review_title: Great benefits, but not a lot of opportunities
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Penn really cares about its employees.  They have excellent time off benefits, unbeatable tuition benefits, and in general, managers here are all very understanding of the need for work/life balance.
cons: Promotions are non-existent.  The only way to move up is to apply for a different job with a higher title, and go through the usual interview process.  On a related note, HR is centralized, but that doesn't really make sense, because Penn doesn't work like a large company:  you can't easily move to a different team or department, and different teams or departments may have very different compensation for the same title & responsibilities.  Essentially, you're trading in career mobility for a few extra days off, and if you're early in your career, that trade may not be worth it.

review_title: My experience working at University of PA
pros: Great benefits (medical, dental, vision, life insurance, retirement savings plan with TIAA Cref and Vanguard), good vacation/paid time off and holidays, and I had a flexible work schedule and the ability to work remotely from home during extra busy times of the year and when the weather was inclement.
cons: If looking to transfer to another unit/department, when applying for jobs, not all posted job openings are truly "open" positions.  In my experience, I have learned when a department wishes to promote an internal candidate, the department is still required to post the position as a "job opening," and it must "go through the motions" and screen a few profiles and offer a "few" interviews to at least 3 candidates.  I have applied for a number of positions where I was perfectly qualified to handle the responsibilities of the position but I was not granted an interview.

review_title: Boring, but hard to complain about benefits
pros: Benefits (health, PTO, etc.) are great, and I have a strong feeling that it would be very difficult for me to lose my job.
cons: The deck is stacked against good culture because of the massive University bureaucracy, but I think the most egregious issues I experience are at the level of my department, The Linguistic Data Consortium.  Management here is cynical and focused on protecting power at the expense of matching skills with needs.  It is also nearly impossible to get a raise above inflation, since such an event requires a title change and being re-hired.

review_title: Not very open to innovation, but decent people and good benefits.
pros:
The take-home salary wasn't that high, but the benefits (taking classes for free, health care, etc) made it very comfortable.
In general the work environment is laid back, and the work rarely follows you home.
For someone with a family it's a great place to work.
cons:
It's an enormous university with tons of red tape and complicated intradepartment politics. Getting anything done that involves something out of the ordinary can be a nightmare.
You end up finding people who aren't good at their jobs/won't do their jobs, but don't get disciplined for it because they've been around so long.
Management is usually out of touch with the reality of what their people do.

review_title: UPenn has a number of staff positions in a diverse and exciting environment.
pros: Benefits are great, including tuition, retirement, health.  Family issues are taken seriously, and personal time is respected.  Hours are flexible depending on staff positions, while environment is very diverse and understanding.  Access to campus events and facilities are a good plus.  There are thousands of staff positions which allow ample of movement and promotions.  Free holiday break in addition to max of 24 vacation days per year.  Preferential treatment for Penn connections when your kids apply as students.  The top staff (President and VPs) are top-paid executives with years of experience in both education and private sectors.
cons: Salary is not competitive compared to the private sector, although tuition benefits might trump the difference if you take classes or degree programs.  Each school is very independent and staff efforts sometimes step on each other due to lack of collaboration.

review_title: Working for University of Penn School of Medicine
pros: The secret to work with Penn is the group you get in with. A great group with a great manager, and it's a good place to work. As an employee you can take any classes you wish, some even towards a degree. Hours are not killer either. Children of employees can get a degree at a much reduced rate, most anyone can get into the College of General Studies.
cons: Like so many other places, my manager was managing only because she had been there for years. She had little mgmt experience and has a shoot first ask questions later approach. I believe there are many others like her within the organization. Projects moved very slowly and they were hardly the most interesting. Almost from my first day I regretted taking the position. It was too laid back for me and not enough interesting work.

review_title: Ivy League School - but not so uptight
pros: It is a well respected institution, with excellent resources (scientists and research equipments) and funding. Great personal growth possibilities, continuing education, invited speakers..  I have good experiences with others sharing resources and co-operative work. The campus is growing, constant construction of new buildings.
cons: Bureaucracy. The hiring process is tedious, the human resources website for job applicants is almost non existing. A few years ago I applied for a job, and they replied to that only 1 year after that (?). It is tedious to deal with the paperwork regarding personal changes (compensation, tax, benefits). No close  parking lot is available, except for medical doctors, professors or higher management, which is annoying. Campus neighborhood towards West  is shaky, every month there is a shooting incident, but if  you avoid going there, you are fine. The benefits for postdocs is disappointing: only 1 type of (cheap) health insurance, no tuition benefits, no FSA account, no 401K.

pros: For anyone beginning their career, this is the place to be. There is an atmosphere that nurtures students, both undergrad and graduate. It also is a place where you learn (maybe for the first time) that there are people that will not like you no matter how "likeable" you are due to things out of your control (i.e. birth place or skin color). You learn to move on, grow tougher skin, and persevere. Life lessons.
cons: It all depends on the particular lab you are, but from what I've seen staff are not exactly treated nicely. And the poor postdocs - well they are nothing but dirt. I feel sorry for them.

review_title: Chaos, no room for growth, and of course a dreadful place to work if you are in the wrong department (Athletics)
pros: Centrally located, many places to eat and many facilities are new. If you play things right, this will be a launch pad to a new job in another department or somewhere else. DO NOT stay longer than 1 year or they have you.
cons: Was in the Athletics department, what a nightmare. Most of management is corrupt/incompetent. Nothing is official, and you get cheated out of your vacation pay if you aren't careful. They play many games, but this is normal. No room for growth unless you are a lifer. Turnover is of course through the roof. Trust no one.

review_title: Amazing breadth of opportunities for students
pros:
Research positions are available in tons of places (not just in sciences)
If you are a freshman, I recommend getting in a research job in any department.  Regardless of whether it is in your major or not.  For someone just out of high school, getting real world experience as early as possible is in my experience the fastest way to figure out what you want to after graduation.
cons: Can be hard to juggle classes and work, especially if you get really involved in your work.  Sacrifices have to be made, and sometimes, that can be your social life.

review_title: Very flexible workplace, great benefits, but no room for growth.
job_title: Research Specialist D in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Flexible work hours
medical, dental , and  tuition benefits are outstanding
cons: There is virtually no room for growth within a position. Whereas responsibilities change and increase over time, pay and title don't follow. The annual "raise" is an  across the board incremental increase with absolutely no room for merit increase based on performance.in your rating system below, please separate compensation from benefits. There is value in looking at the combination, however, you are missing an opportunity t o tease out information. Benefits=5 stars, compensation =2 stars, so 3 for an average.

review_title: Excellent support for professional development; fair compensation
pros:
-Generous retirement package with matching up to 5% after first year of employment
-Winter holiday vacation in addition to generous vacation day accrual
-Fair compensation
-Tuition reimbursement toward undergraduate or graduate degree
-HR staff members offer outstanding professional development programming and one-on-one career counseling
-Opportunity to be in contact with world-class scholarship and research
-Access to first-rate library, lectures, cultural programming
cons: In certain schools and departments, operations can be quite hierarchical.  As can be expected at an Ivy League university, you'll run into some big egos.  Insufficient representation of people of color at higher levels of management.  Communication to administrative-level employees is not always as clear as it could be.  The University is very decentralized, and it can be difficult to find out what's happening in other schools and centers.

pros:
In my department there is not much micromanagement.  Lot of freedom to do your work.  
Just ok pay for the entry level position.
Good amount of time off available and rolls over (not use or lose).
Winter week off for most of organization.
Not required to clock in or work after shift.  No on call or pager.
Not too many meetings.
cons:
Little to no career growth or upward mobility.
Some jobs require working across two organizations which can be difficult.
Some employees do little to no work that places strain on the good workers.
Pay does not commensurate with experience.  
No training and lacking in assisting with gaining experience needed to move upwards.
Sometimes denied essential tools/software needed to do job properly.
Not many lounge or sit down areas for lunch, hope you like lunch at your desk most of the time.
Poor department communication, sub departments are silo'd.

review_title: Radiology Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. Pay versus Happiness
pros: Penn Medicine pay is unbeatable. The benefits are great.  Always updating and buying the newest technology. $8000/yr for education to pursue undergraduate and graduate degree classes. Also has a 75% discount on tuition to the University of Pennsylvania for those with children.
cons: Very political and hostile. High turnover rate and often understaffed. Not a lot of respect or communication. Very hard to feel not on edge or that your job is safe if you make a mistake. Extremely petty and unprofessional when dealing with any conflict.  Many stay because the pay is so good.  Some departments are better than others. No real training. Most new hires who did do clinical at Penn do not make it through probation. Do not expect to ever feel valued.

review_title: Enriching experience at Penn's New Bolton Center
job_title: Research Associate in Kennett Square, PA
pros: Flexible hours, opportunities for subsidized education, culture supportive of personal development, good benefits package especially for children's college tuition
cons: Low salary compared to business world, limited career growth for non PhDs/vets

pros: Great benefits and few accounts of downsizing.  Free undergraduate tuition and partial graduate tuition.
cons: Salaries are lower at University versus corporate since it is a non-profit and you recieve great benefits.

review_title: A great opportunity if you know what to expect
pros: Working as a graduate student and TA was a lot of work, and the take home pay of my stipend was very small, but...I had my entire tuition and fees paid for 5 years. Plus the stipend. So realizing that I was working to literally fund my PhD education helped me not feel totally exploited. There were many opportunities to branch out, from tutoring to lecturing to participating in journal editing reviews to organizing and participating in conferences. Lots of room for growth.
cons: The work will never be done. And it's overwhelming. The training for TAs is also pretty awful, so a lot of undergraduate classes are not well taught unless the graduate student has a natural knack for teaching.

review_title: University of Pennsyllvania is a great place to work
job_title: Financial Administrative Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The University will help you buy a house, has great time off policies, you can get your BA for free, and the environment is very open minded.  I've worked for the University for almost 19 years and I have no complaints until I got a bully manager.   Make sure you get a job there where you have a good experienced manager.
cons: Sometimes the managers can be very bad and the HR department is there for the manager and not for the employee.  I find that working for one of the schools within the University is a better choice the working for the School of Medicine which is more corporate.

review_title: at times stressful, but always rewarding
pros:
Full time employees are allowed to take some classes for free and there's free tuition for your kids/immediate family, which is very nice.  But unfortunately, I only worked part-time.

If you like the area of research you're doing, working with Penn faculty is guaranteed to improve your understanding and thoughts about the field.  Very good research is done, which can be very important if you're looking to attend graduate school later on.
cons: Some PI's are too busy to actually interact with their research assistants.  Pay isn't great, but research assistants never get paid much.

review_title: PennRec, specifically Pottruck gym, is a positive environment to work in and help people pursue their fitness goals.
job_title: SPINNING Indoor Cycling Instructor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I am a SPINNING indoor cycling instructor. At PennRec, I feel I have the freedom I need in order to create and implement my workout profiles and playlists. I also really enjoy building community with my class participants.
cons: I think starting pay could be a bit higher, considering how much physical and mental preparation goes into leading a class. I am about to start my second semester of work with PennRec, so I do not yet know if/how much my pay will increase. But since the instructor is getting a workout, too and can take other classes free of charge, the benefits are more than monetary.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great learning environment, lots of opportunity for growth and working on new and interesting projects. Not a corporate environment. You can have a flexible work schedule as long as you meet expectations. You can have a mentoring relationship with supervisors.
cons: The pay is not on par with the standard of living in Philadelphia. I don't feel like I make a living wage. The only con I have about the job is the pay. I love the work environment, but feel like the pay is well below average. It's unsustainable. There is high turnover.

review_title: Politics Trumps All - Watch Your Back
pros: It's a nice campus, there are good salaries and benefits, perks like the great student gym are nice, and most of my fellow employees were actually quite nice and smart.
cons: Confusing whirlwind of politics means you get mixed messages -- can hear from your immediate manager that you are doing good work but get let go for mysterious, behind-the-scenes reasons.  Some people are very territorial about their field and this can impede collaboration.  They have a 4-month 'test period' so your intitial job security is not good - I moved there for a job and was let go 4 months later, despite being told several times that it was a formality.

review_title: Awesome benefits - no job growth or upward mobility
pros: Awesome benefits, PTO (41 days after 5 years), very little overtime. This is a great job if you have no ambition or desire to climb the management ladder.
cons: As an IT professional, I am working with 10 year old technology and falling more and more behind the industry. There is almost no opportunity for advancement. Since Tom Murphy came on board it seems like the culture is less about the employees and more about drinking the corporate kool-aid. People get hired and dig in like ticks; they never leave so advancement is very rare. You hear about future plans constantly but they never materialize and you end up with little faith in the management.

review_title: Easy student jobs, but they don't pay well
pros: Penn is a great place for students to work. There are so many jobs on campus which are easy and convenient. Many work-study jobs leave you with plenty of downtime for studying or web browsing. I highly recommend a job as an Information Technology Advisor in a college house if you are at all computer literate.
cons: Houry pay rates for some positions have not increased for years. Students may get easy jobs, but they are paid accordingly. If you are willing to work hard and travel off-campus, you can make much more money working part-time in the real world. Of course, you probably won't be allowed to study while on the clock there.

job_title: Prefer Not To Say in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Participating in a worthwhile field, educating the next generation.  Working for an historic university that is highly respected among its peers.  Working with some of the best and brightest faculty in the world.  Access to top-notch healthcare at the University's hospital.  Collegial atmosphere
cons: Very low raises, even for top-level performance.  Old-boy culture when it comes to promotions.  Miserable, miserly "performance increase" scale for annual raises.  These are more like cost of living adjustments, but they are not even as high as the rise in the consumer price index in recent years.  It makes it very difficult to stay, when real pay is effectively decreasing, even given exemplary performance.

review_title: The best work environment I've ever experienced.
pros: I worked in a student services facing office. All of my colleagues were smart, capable, motivated but also down-to-earth. It was a place where you were always challenged but also supported.
cons: The volume of students served was a very high ratio. I was one of two professional staff members serving 4,000+ students. People enjoyed the work environment so much that there were very seldom openings so opportunities for career advancement in terms of title and pay had a long waiting list. (This is why I left.) But I learned a great deal, the benefits were good, and I enjoyed the work environment very much.

pros:
Great vacation time and benefits. If personal growth is a goal, this is a fantastic place to work.
Great learning environment, I have learned so much in this job and have had the opportunity to work with some brilliant people. 
A lot of diversity.
cons:
The pay is not competitive with industry or other academic institutions. There is a lot of turnover and department switching because of this.
The general management philosophy is that there is always room for improvement. Somehow, its never in the areas that need it the most.

review_title: ESAP RTA position for Computer Graphics
job_title: Residential Teaching Assistant (ESAP) in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
When you are a teaching assistant, you're learning too. You're learning through figuring out how to help students, and you're learning from the students too

Good way to learn how to communicate ideas to people

The kids are amazing, and it's always really satisfying to see what they make at the end

I know I can always rely on my Professor for references because of what I've done as a Teaching Assistant
cons:
It's a lot of work. You really need to be involved with your kids 24/7, you have to get to know them. You have to be available 24/7, and be willing to do that. 

And these are high school students, so expect a certain amount of ridiculousness with them.

review_title: The salaries are low in exchange for tuition benefits but supervisors can make it impossible to use the tuition benefit.
pros: If one desires to pursue a career in medical research it is a good experience for those in clinical research.  One can take classes at the University for free provided the supervisor allows it.
cons: During the hiring process one is offered lower salaries than industry and tuition benefits.  However, most supervisors and managers expect one to work very long  hours, making it extremely difficult for one to take advantage of the tuition benefits.  Also, one must apply and meet certain requirements before one is allowed to take most courses.

job_title: Clinical Research Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Great work environment, hourly means no working +40 hr/wk. Intelligent staff to learn from. Opportunity to take classes with tuition reimbursement. Great opportunity for someone interested in going back to school part time. My managers were very supportive of this.
Benefits are decent, my starting salary was typical for the position
cons: Management and work environment varies by lab. For me, I was unable to move up professionally. Everything is grant funded so compensation is not very negotiable, difficult to get significant raises.

job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Perception of making actual difference in the field you are working in.
A lot of hands on experience and great upper management.
Learning opportunities are virtually limitless (though the payment for taxes for the courses are bit of a dud which should be addressed by HR)
Excellent benefits (healthcare, retirement, time off, etc. are among the best in the market)
cons:
Salary is on the lower side (raise of 2% is slightly higher than the current inflation rate but is still way below par WRT to market)
Tuition benefits are only to a maximum of USD 5000 per semester for graduate courses, which is nothing. HR should amend this rule to at least one course per semester

review_title: A diverse and great place to work.
pros: This is a diverse, highly rated and respected university.  They have excellent benefits and compensation.  You can take classes and earn a degree at a fraction of the cost.  Your children, if accepted to the University, will get 75% of their tuition paid for and 50% at other institutions.  The Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania is in the top10 and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School is in the top 2 of the country.
cons: Parking is not free and there is a waiting list for certain garages.  Salaries are low to average for new workers.

pros: All my past experiences working at Penn were all positive & great experiences until I started working at Penn Medicine in Woodbury Heights NJ. Policies & Rules do not apply to all staff here.
cons: Hostile environment to work at! I'm no longer curious why 75% of the staff is only employed here for 1 year when the facility has been open for 6.  They have a quick turnover & I clearly see why. They turn their patients away to Urgent Care. They are heartless and rude.  They had out narcotics prescriptions monthly when these patients should be sent to Pain management!

review_title: As a postdoc it all depends on your Professor and how he runs the lab
pros: Can be a rewarding research experience and great lab environment, depending on the lab. In terms of funding, School of Medicine generally have enough, while for example, Chemistry department labs can be pretty broke.
cons:
Can be hostile environment, depending on the lab. I've seen it both ways here. While funding may or may not be great, the postdoc salary remains poor, although this is the case in most other places anyway. 
There is very little communication between research groups. It is both the closed architecture of space, enormous size of institution, University culture, and maybe something else, that makes people and labs pretty alienated here.

pros: They have all the resources you can ever imagine to complete your research in field of Immunology.  It is one of the best place to work in this field as you have access to advise, suggestions and collaborations of very intelligent scientific community in the field of Immunology
cons: As this University does cuttig edge research, becomes quite stressful at times as you need to perform at your best and as fast as you can.  As a post doc with family and living 40 miles away from the campus, my life was tough. but some one who has no other responsibilities and research is the only goal in life then this place works best.

review_title: great place to be a researcher, lots of resources. teachers not so much.
pros: tough academic environment makes it a great place to grow intellectually. best for research oriented people, since there are lots of resources for collaborations. lots of great minds here and people willing to give good advice at no cost.
cons: sometimes people are too focused on research and not enough on teaching. if you are passionate about teaching, don't count on your teaching abilities to get you tenure. it's the papers and grants these people care about. moreover there are a lot of protocols and restrictions for research studies that makes it rather annoying for you to get things done. the bureaucracy takes precious time out of your schedule.

review_title: Depends on the department you work within.
pros:
GREAT benefits, in fact this is probably what keeps most people at Penn; tuition benefits for yourself and your children, as well as generous leave and 401(k) options. 
If you can take the good with the bad, you can meet some great people, get a free degree, and there are always cool events going on around campus.
cons:
It is a large system and there are a lot of people there that clearly don't care about their jobs; in many ways it is similar to working for a large bureaucracy, tons of red tape, lots of waste and bitter people there who aren't doing their job properly.
Most of the admin staff lives in NJ or is very young and perusing a degree at Penn.

pros: UPenn is a fantastic place to work either as faculty or as a doctoral fellow. Researchers are provided with ample funding, good healthcare benefits, and negotiable workweeks. Due to the university's healthy endowment fund, continued opportunities arise for programming in one's area of interest. The university also significantly has increased its workplace offerings of lactation spaces for nursing mothers. This coupled with the Family Resource Center enable working parents to have a better transition back to work. The security presence on campus is also fantastic.
cons: UPenn's location is its only downside. Philadelphia's crime situation continues to be horrendous and though campus itself is extremely safe, veering a few blocks in either direction without a Penn escort can be dangerous. All workers must seriously consider their daily commutes.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Very relaxed and egalitarian academic atmosphere. Highly engaged faculty and strong student-faculty interactions. Collaborative, non-competitive environment. Graduate students have access to research in some of the best labs in the world and research in labs is primarily driven by graduate students, rather than postdoctoral fellows. Due to the large number of high quality labs on campus, students are not limited with regards to research options. Strong student community and high quality of life.
cons: More support could be provided to students with regards to dissertation preparation. While classes focus on developing student's knowledge bases for both the intellectual and practical sides of research, little there is little focus on the ways in which a student should approach a thesis question or spearhead a dissertation project.

review_title: Student worker while finishing MS degree with a focus on molecular biology
pros: Great experience - but you have to make sure you get with a lab that teaches you what you want to know.  Supervisor was a great mentor. There was some work that I wasn't too fond of, but it was worth it when I got to learn more complex techniques, & I get to put Perelman on my resume.  The schedule was always flexible & I could work around my classes. No weekend work expected.
cons: Pay. Even with a work-study grant, you won't be able to pay your rent in Philly... think of it as food money... or the fact that you're just working for experience.

review_title: Great work-life balance, benefits, and enrichment, poor pay and zero opportunity
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Extremely good benefits, stable employer, beautiful campus with amenities and resources, prestigious and culturally significant institution, convenient location. Academia has extremely flexible hours and a laid-back atmosphere, even in busy times. Working in medical research can expose you to a variety of impressive experiences.
cons: Due to the realities of grant funding, academia underpays, can tend to overwork/stretch job descriptions, and has very little opportunity for advancement. Raises are essentially unheard of, in fact are rigidly controlled and discouraged by the HR system, and employees essentially either stagnate or move on. PI's are extremely busy doctors who trend toward a demanding and dismissive/flippant attitude toward delegation, regardless of their people skills.

pros:
- Some nice people.
- Generous paid time off.
- Good tuition benefits for your children.
- Good healthcare plans (although employee contribution requirements are too high).
cons:
- Salaries low unless in upper management.
- Parking expensive and convenient lots have no vacancies.
- Location is awful (West Philly) and driving in and out is a nightmare.
- Many unqualified people in positions they shouldn't be in.
- The "Peter Principle" runs rampant.
- Tuition benefits for staff limited to Penn education.
- Life insurance policy is poor compared to other higher ed institutions.
- Too big and decentralized creates numerous issues.

review_title: Penn is an excellent place to work providing world class service to tomorrow's industry leaders.
job_title: Associate Director of Mail Services in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Penn has a long established and diverse company culture. There are many activities going on around campus, both work related and extra curricular.
cons: The organization is so large it is difficult to navigate all processes. Each department tends to look out for its own best interests making work harmony difficult to achieve.

review_title: University of Pennsylvania is a great place to work, but the system has flaws that frustrate advancement.
job_title: Research Specialist D in Phila, PA
pros: Penn is a community of terrific people, opportunities for collaborative efforts, continuing education at all levels, all  based in a vibrant city.
cons: There are limited opportunities for professional growth as a staff member in research. You often have one job title, but actually perform a different job altogether. HR designed many job titles, but they are unevenly applied and at the whim of the supervisor.

review_title: Great Place to be a Biomedical Science PhD Student
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Very affordable compared to any other East Coast major city. The Penn Biomedical Graduate Student (BGS) stipend is very competitive with every other Med School-based PhD program, but the cost of living is much lower than NYC, SF, LA, DC, or Boston. Wide-ranging multidisciplinary labs to choose from
cons: Some departments are weaker than others and there is not consistent courseload expectations between programs. Some like Biochemistry and Molecular Biophysics (BMB) have a computer stipend ($1500) and no teaching requirements. Others require up to 4 semesters of TA-ships

job_title: Senior Business Systems Analyst/IT Project Manager/Tech Team Lead in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Laid-back & collegial work environment; many opportunities for flexible work options to achieve work/life balance; great tuition & retirement benefits.
cons: Decentralized & highly political environment requires everything to be achieved via consensus-building, achieving buy-in from many varied stakeholders with conflicting priorities, and tenacity to staying focused on the end-goal.  Many processes and projects take an inordinate amount of time to achieve.

review_title: Fight fight if you want to grow up and get promoted!! Do not give up !
job_title: Senior Research Investigator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great scientific environment, it is easy to set up collaborations. Great speakers quality during various seminars. Great benefits package..
cons: Compared to academia, pay is not good and not fair..You also have to fight very very hard to get promoted and get a better salary although HR is always trying to slow you down and reduce your salary (even if you bring lots of funding) because it has to be fair with other employees ! Let the people competent and motivated grow as much and as quick as they should !!!

review_title: Library Assistant at the Museum Library
pros: Given my pay, I did very little.  Lots of evenings spent watching Gilmore Girls, Gossip Girl, and Glee instead of shelving books.  My relationship with my supervisor was very positive and the entire experience was incredibly useful for me, both in learning how a library works and in gaining some additional cash while I was a student.
cons: The office could be a bit depressing at times, and it was a bit of a hike from my apartment.  There may have been mold in some of the walls.  Some of the full-time staff also seemed extremely depressed with their jobs which was a bit of a downer.

pros: Office culture is very diverse, motivational, and friendly. There are several opportunities for advancement  in regards to overtime and volunteering across the campus. Also, "the other duties as assigned" section in the job description allows you to gain experience through various special projects that aren't necessarily related to one's job. The healthcare benefits are second to none and the tuition benefits allows one to receive a degree at a severely reduced rate. Lastly, there are many online as well as in person professional development programs.
cons: Compensation may not be on par with other universities. Also, working with students at an ivy league institution can be challenging due to the aggressive and competitive learning environment.

pros: The University offers great benefits and a work-life balance. It's a huge employer so there are lots of people to meet in ways to get involved if you seek them out
cons: It is an extremely uncreative environment, a lot of barriers between departments exists and so there is little collaboration. It is a highly bureaucratic environment where everything takes ten steps. Employees are not passionate about their work or the organization itself. Also an extremely wasteful environment in all senses of the word.

pros: UPenn is an ivy league school, so if you're here, the department is probably good for what you do. UPenn is really well known for a lot of things, so if you're an academic, it's good for that.
cons: The benefits as a postdoc at UPenn are not very good. There is no retirement plan for all postdocs at the University. You also don't have access to discounts like pre-tax train/parking passes. Full medical/dental is provided for me at least (though I'm not sure if that's a University wide thing or not).

review_title: Tough times everywhere, doing the best they can in the current environment
job_title: Assistant Professor, Tenure Track in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great resources. Fewer silos than other places of comparable NIH funding. Pretty open and collaborative.
cons:
Like all places with tenure, you are subject to binary decision making on tenure. Tenure is unnecessarily difficult process full of ambiguity.

Turning into a stepping stone rather than a destination during early to mid career, but filling upper ranks with established members. The latter is good for stemming losses and a win-win for parties involved. Not much choice with ever diminishing revenue nationwide

review_title:
Great Benefits for attending college.
Not the best for support from your superiors.
pros:
College tuition is paid for if you need a degree.
Undergrad is totally free.
Grad school has a few strings attached.
Networking potential.
cons:
If you aren't in good with your boss, nothing will happen for you. Even if you do your job well.
You HAVE to know the right people.
There are unfortunately people who are at the top who do not encourage growth because that could derail their level of comfort.

review_title: Nice environment, little opportunity for advancement
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator C in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Work with good, intelligent people. Great PTO, decent benefits, flexible work hours (in my group), great campus and access to amenities.
cons: Very little effort expended by University overall to keep good employees who want to learn, excel, and advance. Low pay with little opportunity for advancement leaves little motivation to stay, while low performers are often kept in their jobs for years and years, bringing down morale.

job_title: Director of Regulatory Affairs in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great benefits! Supportive of the Clinical Research community and definitely areas for growth within that field. Great work life balance. Tuition benefits for you and your dependents are wonderful!!
cons: I don't really have cons as I have worked for this company in many areas for over 20 years. However if I had to pick one it would be salary in reference to the clinical research positions. this is often expected considering it's an academic  health center. Thus people often start out her and eventually move on to industry.

job_title: Grants and Contracts Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The job is demanding, but the work environment and culture are second to none.  this is a entry role into research and research administration and a great starting point for a new career in that direction.
cons: The workload can be a little daunting at times and there is a fair amount of turnover (usually due to people taking advantage of other roles at Penn), leading to more work to accommodate being shorthanded.

review_title: Intellectually stimulating workplace with benefits that are hard to beat
pros: Penn is an incredible place to work. In addition to the intellectually stimulating nature of working in academia, I enjoy the benefits of working on a college campus such as lectures, workshops, and university resources (library, etc.). Additionally working at Penn offers amazing benefits in terms of vacation time, sick days, regular cost of life raises, health/dental insurance, retirement contributions, and best of all - tuition benefits! Get a free degree while you work!
cons: Penn is very decentralized - there is little communication between the 12 schools, so sometimes you miss out on opportunities due to lack of hearing about it.

review_title: So far, as an undergraduate researcher my experience has been wonderful.
pros: The professors are great to work with. I work in a group of doctoral students and I do the same caliber of work that they do. Professors are very receptive to your input, which is refreshing because I know that is not necessarily the same at other institutions.
cons: I wish Penn better integrated other disciplines. All they claim to try to integrate knowledge and even have endowed professorships through the "Penn Integrates Knowledge", with the four schools I still find Penn academically decentralized.

review_title: I enjoyed learning about its diverse programs and offerings and the collaborative work environment
pros: Provides valuable experiences, from working with colleagues with institutional knowledge and opportunities to learn from staff with advanced and specialized skill sets. From top-down, a spirit of innovation, collaboration and helping others flourishes in a strong culture and work environment.
cons: I would say addressing and attempting to overcome cultural perceptions about the organization from the local community and other working professionals. Providing access and encouraging more residents from the local community to utilize its vast resources, including its facilities and academic programs, would help in maintain positive relationships and strengthen ties with the community.

review_title: Very good benefits, but salary not competitive
pros: Opportunity to make a difference,  good benefits, name brand organization.   Amy Gutman - not afraid to take a moral stand and guide organization to a higher level.
cons: Extremely political environment.  Main focus seems to be saving face/CYA when problems come up.  Do as we say, not as we do management.  HR policies are archaic - EVERYONE gets same raise whether you're outstanding, mediocre, or on the board of going into discipline.  Paranoid about unions taking over.

job_title: Research Project Manager A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: It felt great to be a part of Penn's mission and supported throughout the university.  Great benefits and work-life balance.  I was constantly challenged and felt as though I really grew there.
cons: The salary is not as competitive as it should be, both for my position and those around me.  Lack of transparency in salaries and HR policies also made it a distrustful environment.  Some people in higher management positions seemed to lack management skills.

review_title: Fantastic institutional support, particularly health care.
pros: Health coverage for those who live near the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania and Childrens Hospital of Philadelphia was tremendous. Collegial environment with great people.
cons: Salaries are lower, but so is cost of living. It can sometimes be tough to bridge the divide between some of the ultra-fancy students and the regular folks who live in Philly and work at the university, but that is certainly a worthwhile goal that everyone needs to be on board with. There are some good neighborhoods to live in Philly, but they need to get better. It is still a tough place to raise a family.

review_title: Education and Tuition Benefits are a MAJOR bonus
pros: The tuition benefits are probably one of the best perks of working at Penn.  In fact, they are encouraged by the school and management.
cons: For the younger crowd just entering the work force.... Universities can usually find cheap student labor so you run the risk of being underpaid.  They also like to hire temp workers for administrative jobs and treat them like workhorses (temps are also not offered health benefits).    This is not true in every case but I have definitely seen this first hand- and the temp was a Penn grad!

review_title: After 11 years, still one of the best employers in the city of Philadelphia
job_title: Research Specialist B in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Benefits are pretty awesome, particularly vacation & retirement.  Amazing education opportunities.  If you take a job here and *don't* get a degree from Penn, you're pretty dumb.
cons: Very silo'd.  Hard to meet people outside your work group.  Sometimes the bureaucracy is a killer.  And HR is there to protect the university, not employees.  Finally, there's a big distinction between the way staff are treated and the way faculty is.

pros: If you are committed and put in your time, opportunities arise, not necessarily to the top, but certainly, to higher positions, especially if your willing to work for different departments. They also offer financial aid for graduate programs if you work for them full time. Various training opportunities.
cons:
The hierarchy and bureaucracy can be annoying. Sometimes you have to talk to several people to get things done. 

Penn rarely closes for snow days.

pros: It is close to the city and easy to access even when SEPTA goes on strike. Customer service within Penn is usually pretty good. People are helpful. You can take free classes and UPenn also helps you purchase a house if you would like to permanently reside in Philly. It is easy to collaborate across schools and departments.
cons: Faculty could be much more diverse and several faculty members can be challenging to work with. The politics between faculty varies by department and school.

review_title: Working at Penn is great, just be prepared to be flustered by your environment.
pros: The university's Paid Time Off benefits are excellent (the special winter vacation and generous vacation alotment); I have a 35 hour work week (which not everyone has), which makes having kids very doable. I also am fortunate to have flexibility from my boss and workplace, in general. Being at the University also provides a reasonable sense of shelter from economic turmoil. The bottom line isn't the driving force, so we can do with less, but jobs rarely are threatened. Also, Penn provides tuition benefits to faculty and staff and their families. I know Harvard doesn't even have as nice of a benefit as Penn. This means free Wharton! Who wouldn't want that?
cons:
In general, salaries are lower than in the corporate world, but I can accept that because I have generous time off and flexibility.
The parking and transport options are not optimal. I pay $140 a month to park. I could do public transport for about half, but it's hard when commuting with kids (which I do). I realize the limitations of an urban campus, though.

There's a core dysfunction at Penn that I think stems from the decentralization of the schools and depts. The overall culture is very independent, and while Dr. Gutmann has made great efforts to develop programs that inspire interdisciplinary scholarship, the underlying management and information infrastructure is still so fractured that as we try to be more efficient, the legacy makes it extraordinarily difficult.

review_title: Great benefits almost make up for not-so-great salaries
pros: The benefits here are great.  You can take undergraduate classes for free (6 a year) or take graduate classes for a significant discount.  Paid vacation starts a 3 weeks and works up to 5, and on top of that the university shuts down between Christmas and the New Year.  12 sick days a year means never having to use vacation to stay home sick.  Many departments offer flex time and work at home options.  Retirement benefits are excellent.  For those with children, Penn has great tuition benefits for dependents.  If you're on your way to retirement in the next 10-15 years, Penn would probably be one of the top 10 employers in the country.
cons: The biggest downside to working at Penn is HR.  Penn HR controls salary decisions for everyone, even Penn employees whose salaries are paid by an external grant.  In addition, Penn HR is painfully cheap.  Salaries are significantly lower than elsewhere, and raises are usually limited to a 5% max.  Other rules regarding raises basically guarantee no more than a 3% raise in a normal year.  Recently, due to the recession, Penn decided to cut back on salary costs by further limiting raises;  now they are about 1.5%.  Raises, like salary, are determined centrally by Penn HR regardless of who actually provides the money to pay you.  If you change jobs within Penn, HR gets to decide whether you can get a salary increase or if you have to keep the same salary.  This makes Penn a poor career choice for younger people who aren't getting ready to retire.

review_title: Great Benefits and Work Life Balance
job_title: Research Specialist A in Phila, PA
pros:
Great tuition benefits. Staff can take classes for free as soon as they start work.
Easy hours -- Could just be my department, but hours are generally very flexible and allow for you to take care of other things that go on in life.
cons: Low pay is my only con. I also feel like there are not many opportunities for staff to get together, but this may just be a function of the fact that there are numerous departments here.

job_title: IT Support Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
- Flexible Hours
- Freedom of convenience (when to finish cases, what order, how, etc...)
- Simplified Payroll Reports (online, spreadsheet)
- Access to ITA tools (antivirus, etc)
cons: Management does not necessary understand what each case means, so they are sometimes dubious of longer cases (reformatting harddrive and reinstalling operating systems, things of those nature). However, if you are patient and explain, they are very cooperative.

review_title: I love my colleagues, the benefits, work-life balance and great environment of academia
pros:
-Earn your graduate degree - one of many excellent benefits
-World renowned scholars and leaders come to speak
-Great system in place for feedback and collaboration across the university, if you make the effort
cons:
-There are many lifelong staff = sometimes upward movement can be difficult
-It can take forever and a day for technology to improve and be approved (which is not very good in today's environment where tech rules)
-There aren't bonuses or easy promotions - if you're going above and beyond your job responsibilities you'll get a thank-you but not financial compensation

review_title: Mostly doing this to access rest of site...
job_title: TA for Summer Course in Phila, PA
pros: You are always surrounded by smart people who want to build stuff all the time.  Exhausting if you have to account for all of them but the drive is there.
cons: More red tape than most other larger universities that I know of.  Compared to its peer institutions (Brown, Duke, Dartmouth) it just has a lot more bureaucracy to haggle with.

pros: As a PhD student at UPenn, if you can hack it, you know that you are set for your next professional step.
cons: Being a PhD student is very lonely and insecure. I would only recommend it to someone dead set on earning very little salary for up to 8 years and motivated to do nothing but research, which is a very insecure prospect since one cannot be certain it will always work.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Penn has a great network of researchers and clinicians to draw from for your research.  Philadelphia is a great place to live and get around.  Stipends in engineering are pretty good.
cons: The graduation requirements in the college of engineering seem to morph every year, kind of confusing.  A lot of the engineering courses are poorly taught and the overall selection of courses for graduate students is limited.

review_title: Overall has been a very good experience
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: There is a good sense of comraderie within the department and in general people are willing to share both information and equipement, etc.  There are ample opportunities for learning new things, whether through a seminar or having a presence of different biotech companies demonstrating new products or services.
cons: Being a postdoctoral fellow means you get the short end of the stick pretty much anyplace, however at Penn the so-called postdoctoral council which is supposed to help us out really does nothing but hurt and the administration constantly feels the need to screw us over - usually in the form of salary  which is a joke to begin with.  Here the admin feels that your PI cannot pay you as they wish (which would be higher b/c you cannot pay lower than the federal std) and that they are not responsible for giving you FISCAL year pay raises until your contract comes up again - if that's in June then you basically lose out on a year's worth of pay rise that is not back-compensated at the time of your contract renewal.  This means that a 4th year postdoc could be making less than a second year for any amount of time it was their misfortune to have signed a contract.

review_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in the Department of Psychiatry at University of Pennsylvania
pros: Great place to work, good benefits, and friendly co-workers are the best reasons to work here.  They also allow you to take 2 free classes per semester if you are working full-time.
cons: Lots of paperwork and long processing times for every interaction with HR or the business office makes things that should be simple a lot more complicated and time consuming.

pros:
Ability to do research based consulting (in one of the research centers) in the area of choice
Excellent collegiality
Challenging and relevant problems
cons: The outside world sees university based employment as irrelevant, even though in several years of consulting experience, this experience is second to none. Actually, better than both large, branded consultants as well as niche players

pros:
1)"free" tuition - discussed more in cons below, but who can argue with a degree at Penn. 
2) Just working for Penn is prestigious and people are impressed by it. 
3) You won't find much better benefits elsewhere. VERY generous time off, many paid holidays - I would say about 5 weeks a year are paid time off. 
4) laid back environment - many positions are a little more laid back than industry.
cons:
1)"free" tuition actually costs you money - You only get the first 5500 in graduate tuition free, then you have to pay a 35% tax on the rest, some of which you get back at tax time. It sounds great, until you realize that each class is 5500+ and that you have to pay about 2000 per class just in taxes. You could just pay for school at another institution for what you pay in taxes for classes. 
2) It can be hard to find classes that fit around your schedule. 
3) Many people seem to do the LPS program, which seems to basically be a shadow program for employees to take. It gives the Penn name, but it's not really the same as a real academic program in my opinion. You should really apply for a real program in a school there. 
4) I work in the medical school - if you aren't a MD or faculty, be prepared to be a 2nd class citizen in all ways. Even PhDs are seen as lesser people. 
5) The school may have 12 billion dollars in endowment, and the MD school may have received a 250 million dollar gift from a single person, and they might be building a million buildings all the time, but come raise time, get ready for them to talk about how they don't have much money this year. Most of the time my department wanted to give me more money, but the school restricts it. A 2.5% raise doesn't even beat inflation, so you are making less each year. 
6) If you want to advance, you really need to apply for a different job in the university. Positions don't grow very much here compared to industry. 
7) not much negotiation for salary.

review_title: You have to fight for your career advancement
pros: PENN is a great research institute where a lot of exciting studies are being conducted. Work is challenging and exciting. Work-life balance is good for they provide a lot of flexibilities.
cons: There is no defined career advancement ladder. Work is done by a small percentage of employees. Other people are taking a "free ride". You have to fight for your own promotion and every process drags on forever.

review_title: The Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania
pros: The connections I have made at the University of Pennsylvania are great because the network in which these people are a part of is vast and expansive.
cons: As an intern Working for the Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology there is very little funding to the museum and there are no paid spots available for entry level positions.

review_title: Overall, the experience at Perelman Quadrangle was positive.
pros: Everyone here is very friendly. Just don't get too comfortable. This is more of an entry level place where once you have your foot in the door at Penn, you move onto other departments. Benefits(med, vision, dental) are good and you have the opportunity for an Ivy League education for free.
cons: The only con that I have for my experience is my job was highly repetitive. There are no special projects; it's pretty much the same thing day in day out. This leaves little room for personal/professional growth. The pay is not great.

job_title: Systems Programmer Senior in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Location, good quality of life benefits, and stability. There is a variety of job types in this largish organization and Penn is a leader in implementing new technologies.
cons: Penn's IT is very decentralized and political at times. This is often a hinderance in getting work done. Some services offered were very bad deals for customers; prices were high and quality of the service was poor and often very limited compared to the "real world". The organization was tasked with supporting too many different systems without enough people to truly do an outstanding job.

pros:
My boss is honest, brilliant and very much innovative. My organization had taught me a lot to improve myself and the management team is very supportive and always encourages new ideas. My company is one of the best platforms to prove ourselves.

I'm kindly informing you that it's not my character to speak out about the secrets or negative/weak points of a third person for my sake in his absence. Not only about my boss, about anybody as I've certain values. I think that's not good manners. So, I'm extremely sorry madam/sir, simply I can't say.
cons: very good and I like it

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: World experts are at your fingertips, in a highly collaborative environment that fosters excellence in medical and basic science research
cons: Recognition of Postdoctoral Fellows as full employment status and all benefits therein are lacking. This is true at many institutes but as a leader in training and research this falls short, and fails to retain highly talented postdocs in the academic arena

job_title: Research Specialist B in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Good access to knowledge and a good place to learn new techniques at an entry level.
cons: Ridiculously fast paced in translational research lab. May have to deal with intelligent people that have no emotional intelligence.

review_title: Administrative Coordinator but held various other positions at Penn
pros:
Good vacation time including week between XMAS & New Years, decent sick policy,
Health insurance is OK - not the worst but not the best considering the access to medical school, Schie Eye and Dental School.  Decent tuition benefits if you want to get your undergraduate degree.  Decent tuition benefits for your child.  Some benefits like disability and sick time have been improved so it is a start - they are looking at paid family leave - will see how that goes
cons: No room for advancement, management needs some people training, low pay, not very flexible - they talk a good game with flexible working conditions but try getting them is a whole other story.  Performance management is a joke - does not really matter if you are a stellar employee or a just meets requirements employee - everyone gets the same raise so there is no incentive to be a stellar employee as you will not get a higher raise and rarely are there opportunities to be promoted.  Very much depends on which part of the university you work - each school is like it's own fiefdom with little fiefdoms within them - very decentralized system with their own rules and regulations.  Pretty much most of HR duties has been outsourced - apply for jobs online only, all benefits applications are outsourced so you are not really sure what exactly Penn's remaining HR folks do - they have a whole compensation department that looks at reclassifying positions - good luck with that - rarely does a reclassification to a higher level occur.  If you are really good at your job - management wants to keep you locked into that job and even internal promotions are hard to come by as they want to keep you locked down into your current position.  Some resistance to change by people that have been at Penn for a long time (I myself have been here for 25+ years and have worked in 3 different areas at Penn).

review_title: Your direct supervisor has the most influence on how awesome or crappy your worklife is.
pros: excellent tuition benefits, flexible work schedules (unlikely that you will have to clock in and clock out, but this depends on your job and your supervisor and your department), special winter vacation between Christmas and New Year's off for all employees that doesn't count against your vacation time, exposure to lots of fairly smart people, opportunities to interact with young motivated people, opportunities to take advantage of benefits aimed at students but available to all Penncard holders (library, free advance screenings to movies, public speakers- usually famous, often celebrities like Bono and others who are highly successful in their respective fields), constant construction means that at some point your facilities will be renovated, food trucks, relatively compact campus
cons: Academic world equals less pay than the corporate world. Similarly titled job positions may lead to vastly different experiences due to leadership and internal politics. Not everyone is smart or interested in performing well and they may be paid as much or more than you. Your direct supervisor will make all the difference in what your real day to day (not on paper) job expectations will be. It can be very difficult to have issues about management addressed due to bureaucracy and departmental/management bias. Some groups work great together and in others, office politics rule. (When you interview, try to get contact info for people who work there or who left the position to get the scoop and make sure that if hours are required not during the normal 8-5 time frame that you get a written description of what those hours are going to look like. Ask what the current hours for the position look like.)

review_title: Library assistant in Van Pelt library, Rosengarton Reserve Desk
pros: Quiet relaxing job that you can even have your time to finish your homework in the while working. The partners and supervisors are nice and willing to help. The working site is the Van pelt which is a convenient site to go every in the university.
cons: Just one thing: low pay, not surprising right ? Also some shift are covering the lunch or supper time which means you can only have a very simply meals like sandwich or you can choose to endure the hunger and eat after the shift.

pros: Good benefits, great environment, nice perks
cons: Upper management removes employees by "eliminating"  their positions, not necessarily because of job performance but because they "don't like you".   Management not qualified at times and are kept rather than being terminated.  Penn stands behind their managers regardless of their errors.  Sometimes BAD errors.  Saw it happen many times in Development and Alumni Relations Dept.  Penn has eliminated positions of people at the University that were there 10+ years.  Sometimes 20+ years.

pros: Fantastic facilities, great people. Pay is middle range for Philadelphia, but tuition benefits are good if able to take. Working with top notch students every day is rewarding and invigorating.
cons: Bureaucracy is pretty rough at Penn, lot's of silos to navigate and separation of various departments makes collaboration difficult. Money issues that flow through the campus both with students and donations makes politics a bit hard to navigate.

pros: Penn has a very active graduate student community, with many cross-disciplinary initiatives. In addition, my advisor has been very flexible about time off and doesn't keep track of graduate student's time, which I gather is common amongst other labs, but not always the case.
cons: Difficult to address situations with one's PhD advisor. If a graduate student is in an undesirable situation in his/her lab, there doesn't seem to be a good route to take. This is endemic to nearly all PhD programs at Penn and elsewhere, but it would be nice to see bigger initiatives to address this.

pros: You are surrounded by incredibly bright people who want to make a difference. Lab team tend to be generally helpful in making sure you learn and are able to make a meaningful contribution.
cons: Many people at Penn want to do research, so competition can be tough. Additionally, it may not always be clear how to perform certain duties since you're new, but this common.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chagrin Falls, OH
pros:
Excellent Pay (12 an hour eventually 14 an hour) 
Excellent Staff
Well Organized
Flexible with other commitments(Exams,Interviews)(This is coming from a current students perspective)
cons: They only allowed me to start off at three hours per week and sometimes when I went in to tutor I had no one to teach so I wouldn't get paid. Also, the students are sometimes asking for answers and not actually wanting to learn.

pros: Working in customer service with UPenn allowed me to meet and connect with all different types of people, helping me to become a more multi-culturally sensitive person.
cons: As with any community, working with a few members who believe they are continually the exception to all rules can become frustrating. As a lower level employee, constantly having to bring in my supervisor to discuss rules and regulations in more detail could become an interference in my own work.

review_title: Benefits great; pay and flexibility is limited for DAR staff
pros: Health benefits are great and PTO is good once you have worked there for a few years
cons:
Pay scale is lower than other ivy leagues and once you are set with your salary when you accept your position, it is difficult to get a substantial raise without leaving and returning again to the institution
website advertises work flexibility is an option but in the Development and Alumni Relations (DAR) area, it is frowned upon

review_title: Getting a PhD is all about playing the long game.
pros: Lots of fantastic people doing world-class research.
cons:
Choose your advisor carefully: a difficult one can make things very challenging for you. When you visit/interview with prospective PIs, make sure you not only talk to people from the group, but also to grad students in other groups in the same department. You will get a well-rounded perspective of what it's like to work in that group.
