Also, unsurprisingly, salaries for PhD students are much lower than what you could get in industry with a bachelor's, and no 401k matching either.

pros: This job had very good pay (compared to my peers) and provided me with experience in the medical field that has given me a leg up post-grad. Boss was friendly and great to work with. All coworkers kind.
cons: There was nowhere near 40 hours of work to do a day. Little to do when assigned projects were finished. Coworkers were mostly 10+ years older than me.

pros: They have the best benefits package i've ever had on any job, and when looking at others they really stand out.  If you're a nurse or Dr the sky's the limit for you, in terms of career trajectory.
cons: Unless you're a nurse or Dr, you're pretty stagnant.  It's the definition of a trap.  They only worry about following guidelines when they know there's a site visit from JCAHO, it's actually pretty entertaining to watch them run around checking for things that literally go on every other day of the year, business as usual.

pros: Flexible hours for students, letters of recommendation
cons: never interact with the PI; extremely low pay; expected to work overnight shifts during the school week (11 pm- 7:00 am); verbally abusive toward new employees who are immigrants

review_title: Great place to be a Ph.D. student in robotics. Of course it depends who your advisor is
job_title: Ph D Student in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I have lots of intellectual freedom. My advisor is rather hands off but always supports me in what I want to pursue.
cons: It can take a long time to finnish one's phd here because it is not very guided. You have to be on your own and manage your own time and be able to motivate yourself.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Very good tuition benefits, decent health insurance, flexible schedules, generous PTO, work-life balance, mentoring and professional development opportunities, chance to work with intelligent people
cons: Lower pay than industry, limited opportunities for advancement in my field, bureaucracy and politics sometimes get in the way, annual "merit increases" to pay barely cover cost of living, difficult to get a significant raise.

review_title: Rewarding place to work with great flexibility, but advancement is limited
job_title: Research Specialist D in Philadelphia, PA
pros: benefits are great for all phases of life ( kids, going back to school, retirement) , dependign on particular boss, flexible hours are possible, atmosphere of collaboration wihtin and between labs is a big plus
cons: annual increases are extremely small, there is no structured way to advance so the burden is on the individual to make their case, bureaucracy can get in the way of getting things done

review_title: HR department could use some "freshening up"
pros: While we as managers shoot for the ideal of no turnover, HR has achieved this.
cons: Not having turnover is not necessarily a good thing. A majority of the department is probably a little too comfortable in their roles (having been there forever) thus most of them are going to be their till they retire. I mean who wouldn't want comfortable until they retire. Turnover is good in the respect that it brings new people and new ideas into an organization, which is where the HR department falls short.

review_title: Better than many, but not what it pretends to be.
pros: Known Name. Very large stable entity. Intellectual stimulation daily. Cross fertilization of disciplines.Some stellar medical programs, that have few equals.
cons: One of the faceless masses to the higher levels of leadership. Many of the medical disciplines are lackluster at best.If you are too competent, your boss may feel threatened. It can still be dangerous if you are not a white male.

review_title: Penn has been good to me overall.
pros:
Work Life Balance
Benefits
Opportunities to advance my education
Diverse work force
cons:
Leadership focuses on a few favorites who can do no wrong
Favorite today, gone tomorrow
Inconsistent management 
Short-sighted business practices in terms of compensation and promotion opportunities

review_title: It has been enriching to work at Penn.
pros: One of the best reasons to work at Penn is to be exposed to the great minds of the faculty and researchers.  It is a very inspiring environment.
cons: The downside to working at Penn is the hierarchy that exists between academic staff, associated faculty and standing faculty.  There is a level of eliteness that exists and is promulgated is disturbing.

review_title: No room for growth, looks good to others
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Can work with a lot of names in the field.  Nice amount of time off. Many opportunities to make career moves horizontally - good if you are interested in hopping from project to project.
cons: The culture is completely dependent on who you work under. I have the experience of working under a difficult PI - I feel quite vulnerable to the PI's whims and would not have much recourse if I felt mistreated. Pay is not great and raises are a big uphill battle.

pros: They offer generous benefit packages for management level employees.  Their matching retirement funding is a huge plus that is often over looked.  The educational benefits for children and spouses (not for professional schools) keeps me from pursuing a private sector job.
cons: Difficult to actually schedule/take classes for myself while working full time.

job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Flexibility in the workplace. where and when you get your work done is the best I have experienced. The quality of  people who work here is way above average. The empahasis and support for continuing your education is real.
cons: The salary is not corporate competitive. Surrounding corporate companies in the area generally pay more but the stress at those jobs is also much higher.

review_title: Excellent place to launch an academic career
pros: The work environment is relaxed, research quality is world-class, and collaborators are friendly and almost always willing to help. The cost of living is quite low (even in decent neighborhoods) and you get to live in a very convenient, walkable, and bikable city.
cons: Penn often gets confused with Penn State. Undergraduates can be obnoxious. Some neighborhoods near campus can be dangerous if you don't know what you're doing. The food is mediocre unless you're willing to spend a lot of money on the higher-class establishments.

review_title: UPenn provides quality research experience and offers decent benefits for postdocs.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: There is a lot of money for research. The quality of research is really good. Postdocs are provided excellent benefit package, including health, dental, and vision insurance.  Obviously the experience at UPenn as a post will depend on your PI, so choose your PI wisely.  Many PI's offer flexible hours and you get two weeks of vacation and more sick days than a normal person can use.
cons: We are not provided a retirement package as we are considered contract employees.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
- Benefits (healthcare options, taking 2 classes per semester for free)
- Opportunities to learn about research across departments and institutions
- Free food once or twice a week
cons:
- Stifling bureaucracy in the finance and HR departments
- Poor management leads to overworked employees
- Little opportunity for advancement
- Low salary compared to industry standard

review_title: Flexible hours, relaxed environment, medium bucks.
job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The environment is very relaxed, with flexible hours, nice campus, lots of smart people.  The health/dental benefits are excellent, and it's almost impossible to get fired.  There are always interesting talks to go to in any field you might be interested in.  There's a theater and a museum and a stadium, all on campus.
cons: The large established bureaucratic system makes it difficult to do some simple things, like purchasing (specifically IT).  Many lifers are very slow about getting things done.

review_title: A great opportunity for growth and learning.
pros: The University of Pennsylvania has a great reputation for a reason -- it is one of the best universities in the country and is an excellent center for research.
cons: If you are looking for an incredibly diverse environment, unfortunately the University of Pennsylvania is someone homogeneous.  However, they are working to add diversity to the student and staff population.

pros: Great leader Kham was a great team lead who is very supportive and motivate the team to get every project done before the due date
cons: Upper management has too much politic and not recognize the high potential employees, play favor when come to promotion.

review_title: Enriching and diverse environment conducive to learning and networking.
pros: Networking contacts are readily available for those who seek them. From research, to the humanities, to business, anyone you may want to contact is less than two or three people away, if not less. Networking is encouraged, especially in The Wharton School.
cons: A highly competitive culture can often lead to feelings of inadequacy. Attended and staffed mostly by overachievers creates a tendency to feel as if you're not performing at your best unless you are above the rest.

review_title: University of Pennsylvania has given me the opportunity to grow as a young professional in the drug research field.
job_title: Research Specialist A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The benefits are incredible.  The resources are endless.  The community at University of Pennsylvania is like no other.  You work at an institution that strives for excellence.
cons: Many positions in the research labs of University of Pennsylvania are grant-funded so the salaries are generally more limited than at a pharmaceutical company or other private enterprise.

review_title: A good place to carry research and institute productive collaborations
pros: As a researcher Penn is a wonderful place populated by extremely smart and talented individual that are usually open to share their ideas. Collaborations within different departments is not unusual and probably one of the thing that puts this university at the top with regards to research outputs and results.
cons: Sometime (often) interacting with the business offices personnel and their management can be frustrating due to slow response and lack of feedback on matters that are beyond a researcher call of duty.

job_title: Research Project Manager A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Tuition reimbursement, fairly flexible working environment
cons:
HR stunts employee growth.  Departments wish to promote within and HR makes it nearly impossible, not realizing how much time, money, and resources are wasted in the hiring process and could be avoided if promoting within was a feasible option.  
Grossly underpaid.  
Little to no work-from-home ability although job can easily be done from home. 
Under-performing team members stagnate processes. 
Very little career advancement opportunities.

review_title: Great place to work with smart people, has a very entrepreneurial atmosphere.
pros: Academic environment means you are surrounded by smart people who want to get things done.  It is a great place to hatch new ideas and work in a collegial environment.  Great benefits.
cons: Business administrative staff have a lot of bureaucracy to wade through.  It is difficult to find money to do certain things.

review_title: If I had to choose over I would have never ca here. It's nothing of what it's advertised to be. No advancement No raises
pros: Flexibility ,many workers take advantage of it. They are able to bully other employees  and management  does nothing
cons: Ignorant workers, racist,no advancement favoritism, management  plays employees  against each other encourages tattling and other childish  behaviors

review_title: Worked as a research specialist for 2 years. Work was interesting, learned a lot, some long days.
job_title: Research Specialist A in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Gained a lot of experience, the people in the lab were really cool and easy to get along with. Post-docs really know how to teach laboratory techniques. Supervisors were extremely capable and guided projects very well.
Great benefits
cons: Pay wasn't that great for all the hours that I put in. Some 12hr days as well as weekends were required. Supervisors lack managerial strength.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Provided an opportunity to cut my teeth as a teacher and form lesson plans, interact with students, and learn about teaching in an academic setting.
cons: Pay is on par with adjunct pay, which is kind of ridiculous. No benefits from assisting with teaching a class full-time, and helping an adjunct professor teach for a combined salary that is smaller than a tenure-track professor.

job_title: Assistant to the Chair in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Depending on the School and Department you can work with cutting edge researchers and faculty members with their fingers on the pulse of technology.
cons: Penn faculty can be a little tricky and personalities take time to figure out as a wise person once told me faculty have no training on how to handle administrative roles yet often find themselves having to deal with many administrative duties.  HR in some schools at UPenn is great but extremely weak in other schools and a complete let down to the staff.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Phila, PA
pros: I feel like it has been really easy to balance my academic commitments with my RA position. Professors I work under tend to understand my competing priorities and don't ever push me to come into work at the cost of a grade.
cons: Feel like I'm often left unchallenged, and not very stimulated by what I do. Wish there was an emphasis on training or at least explaining the importance of the larger project at hand.

review_title: You are on your own to research & develop what you want with any intellectual help you need
pros:
Looks good on PhD applications
Extremely smart people
Great academic resources
Cheap, fun city
Great athetic facilities
AWESOME food nearby
cons:
Everyone is super busy, lack of real mentorship
lowish pay
Philadelphia has generally shitty weather during the winter (November through April)

review_title: Great intellectually stimulating place to work, incredibly disjointed organization
pros: Relaxed work environment, 35 hour work week, easily accessible location, vibrant city, intellectually stimulation, great educational opportunities, significant college tuition assistance (including for kids).
cons: A very political place. Organizationally, the University is really an amalgamation of 12 schools and many more 'centers' that all have their own budgets, priorities and leaders and none of them seem to agree on any strategical approach. Salaries not line line with commercial alternatives.

review_title: Lower Salaries, Great Benefits. All departments are different.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: If you live nearby it is wonderful. Tuition. A shuttle that runs around West Philadelphia and in toward center city. I love their gym.
cons:
Everyone i know has a different experience. It all depends on your department. I was at the school of medicine and I never want to work there again. 
Interview them as they interview you. You don't get paid enough to be in an unhealthy work environment.

pros: University Medical Center that values education.  Encouragement by management to continue education.  Tuition reimbursement up to $8000 per year.  Work three twelve hour shifts per week,
cons: May be difficult to attend nursing school full time while working full time, although many make it work and management tries to accommodate school where possible.

pros: There are a wide variety of positions available on campus. Thankfully, most of them are able to work around your schedule. I've worked in IT for the college houses and as a Teaching Assistant for the School of Engineering.
cons: Compensation is not much higher than minimum wage, but being a student, it makes sense. It makes you compelled to take on two jobs in order to actually get a worthwhile paycheck every week to help cover expenses, which can start to eat into your schedule.

review_title: Great, Solid Institution with Brand Awareness
pros: Penn is a great place to work with plenty of opportunity. I have been here for over a decade and would not leave if I didn't have to. Everything on campus is convenient--from doctors offices, to groceries, gifts and public transportation.
cons: Penn is very political and in some ways not as efficient as corporate, but all you need to do is be patient and not allow your ego to interfere.

pros:
Knowledgeable staff.

Strong leadership.

For example, one particular office has a very top-down and well integrated hierarchical structure. Supervision was not overbearing and the ability of supervisory staff to give feedback to and assessments of lower-ranking or new employees was fair.
cons:
Parking can be difficult. 

For those not native to the Philadelphia area, it may take a while to adjust to the pace of the city itself, which may or may not be reflected in one's office of employment.

review_title: A lot of perks with a friendly atmosphere
job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Philadelphia, PA
pros: People are very friendly, it's a great place to work.  There are opportunities for advancement within your position. The pay is competitive.
cons: Management needs some work. It has been the biggest challenge of my job. Management is very distant. Also, transferring between units is difficult.

pros:
1. Excellent benefits package including insurance, gym memberships, and everything else you expect in a university.
2. Employees get tuition benefits if you enroll in a program.
3. Dynamic and highly capable students create an environment where you get exposed to new ideas and new ways of thinking.
4. Lots of new initiatives and centers. there's something for every person irrespective of your interests.
cons: - Like most universities, the setup can be bureaucratic. It's not easy to get things done if you go through the chain of command.

pros: Nice community, decent pay for a part time job, management was really nice when I was there.  As far as summer jobs went it was a good experience.
cons: Sometimes long hours on your feet, and in the summer the uniforms were unbearably hot.  I worked on the healthcare side, so you could have some difficult residents but nothing too bad.

review_title: Great place to work, advancement slow
pros: Great academic environment in a great city.  Always enriching opportunities to take part in, like guest speakers.  Free food is frequent!
cons: Advancement is slow, and while there are lots of interactions with professors and higher-up staff, the division between administrative staff and professors is clear, but perhaps that is how it is in all academic workplaces.

review_title: Great team of scientists, cutting-edge research.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great team of scientists, cutting-edge research, fantastic scientific environment.
cons: Absolutely no benefits for me---no health insurance, no retirement plan, no discount on public transportation, no affordable on-campus parking, zero vacation days.  Besides that many rooms do not have air conditioning, e.g., the temperature in my room varies from 56F in winter to 92F in summer. No feedback is accepted by the management.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator B in Philadelphia, PA
pros: There are some great people if you get into a good cell.
cons: It is absurdly compartmented place with lots of little cells. There is a strong Not Invented Here problem. With the University developing its own calendaring and billing systems in different departments and groups with no consistency across the system and often resulting in poor products which don't work well for their purpose when they can just purchase a better product from someplace else.

review_title: Postdoctoral Fellow at Abramson Family Cancer Research Institute
pros:
- Prestige of institution
- Access to state of the art equipment
- Great sense of scientific community with Children's Hospital and Wistar Institute scientists
- Location
cons:
- Politics permeate the workspace
- Salary is NIH minimum guidelines, benefits are not great and postdocs are neither students nor employees.
- Laboratory space is at a premium.

pros: Top level academics, across a wide range of fields. As a researcher, if you need to collaborate with someone with a particular specialty, you can find them.
cons: Some of the buildings are old and amenities that might be expected (house nitrogen, DI water, etc) are not available in most physical sciences buildings. Graduate students, as is the norm, receive a stipend. It's enough to live on ($28k) and comparable with other institutions, but a little extra cash would be nice.

review_title: BSN Nursing / Lt. Col Veteran USAF
pros: EXPERIENCE, Medical Terminology, Surgery in 26 operating rooms.  Surgeries include: Open Heart, Maxillo-Facial, General, Orthopedics, Neuro,Gyne and Robotics. I was a Senior Level 3 Nurse as a Circulator and Scrub
cons: Call, Overtime, Downsizing, Less Staff, no breaks. Recruitment but not Retainment, heavy lifting, eight to ten cases a day per operating room suite

job_title: Research Data Analyst in Philadelphia, PA
pros: My supervisor is supportive and fantastic. Professional development is encouraged and well-resourced the work environment is collaborative and healthy. Benefits are solid and, if you stay within the Penn Medicine, doctors and staff are well qualified, friendly and share records.
cons: Very de-centralized, hierarchical University structure makes it difficult to network outside of my department, which makes it more difficult to be proactive (rather than reactive) by anticipating questions and needs.

pros: Depending on the department, staff and colleagues can be amazing and become your lifelong friends. Philadelphia is a great city to be in if you love the arts, design, architecture and a nice social life.
cons: Salary/ wage rates sometimes seem low and medical benefits can be difficult to navigate. Some faculty and students can be rude, disrespectful and self-indulgent thereby creating that "Penn bubble" feeling.

pros:
Increase my own knowledge of the subject matter whilst teaching the students. 
Got to meet whole new classes of students coming in.
cons:
Same baseline salary that did not change for the 2 years I worked there. 
Professor was very disorganised and I had to take over the actual teaching of the class a decent amount of times

review_title: Good place to start developing skills with nice guidance
pros: It is a great experience to work with smart minds! You can get instant feedback along with nice guidance from experienced professioals.
cons: The salary is not as much as those out in the field but doing research is not about making money in the first place, so it is not a big con.

review_title: Overall a good place to PostDoc
pros: University's good reputation helps open doors. Good research facilities. Good academic atmosphere. Depending on personal academic advisor, could be a pro.
cons: Postdoctoral fellows have very little access to job/career preparation or assistance. Fierce competition. Health benefits for postdocs are sufficient, but not great for families with kids. Childcare is difficult to find. Depending on personal academic advisor, could be a con.

review_title: I'm very happy with how I've advanced, but there is a pretty hard ceiling.
pros: Of course it depends on the professor you work for, but I've found the university to treat the staff very well, and reward good work. Benefits are quite nice, and I enjoy working in the city as well.
cons: If you're not tenure track there's only so far you can advance in the scientific fields. University environments can be somewhat chaotic, too. Academic salaries are nothing to write home about.

review_title: Penn is a supportive place to work, if you're bright enough to keep up with your peers...
pros: Penn has superb resources, facilities, infrastructure, and most of all, exceptional faculty. The undergrad population is, on the whole, outstanding. Many undergrads participate in research and are truly assets to their faculty mentors.
cons: Penn is a place where very bright people work, but if you can't keep up, you may find yourself out in the cold. Significant achievements are expected on an annual basis, or else….

pros: Penn has stellar faculty and is a very collaborative academic environment.  The access to clinical expertise and patient samples is a huge benefit for research.  A large alumni network and career services program provide support for students looking to enter the job market.
cons: As at any academic institution, federal funding for research is incredibly tight.  As a graduate student it may be difficult to find placement in a lab with guaranteed funding for the next few years.

pros: Competitive, but great working environment.  Relationships with other fellows and students makes every day wonderful.  Great relationships with mentors.  Lots of opportunity to collaborate with others to advance my research.  Good health benefits.
cons: I am fortunate to make a higher salary, but when I first arrived, the salary was barely above the national average.  The cost of living in Philadelphia is higher, so salary should be comparable.  Work-life balance is challenging in a very competitive environment.

pros: Doing my phd degree here. It's an Ivy league school. The requirements of the degree are rather tough, but it forces you to learn and develop. I chose the school for it's excellent research (Mechanical Engineering), and the location is great, close to New York and Washington DC.
cons: To get in was very hard, like at any other top schools, especially for a foreigner like me. Went through GRE and TOEFL tests.

pros: I work within a specific department of a specific school within the University, so your experience may vary. Upenn is a very big, multi-faceted organization. But the specific group I work with is great. Friendly people, good work facility, not much to complain about.
cons: UPenn is a very big organization, so it tends to be bureaucratic in a lot of ways, like any big company. Some things like procuring new supplies for your office can be a pain.

review_title: Positive, supportive environment with limited advancement opportunities and below average salary
pros:
Collegial environment
Generous vacation time and cyclical nature of many offices
Priority given to work-life balance
Opportunity to make a difference in individual lives at key developmental stages
Energy, vitality, and enthusiasm of working with college age students
cons:
Predictable workflow due to cyclical nature of academic terms
Tendency to reify "the way we do things" makes change difficult to implement
Glacial pace of change
Inability to move people along when necessary
Salary and advancement opportunities for non-tenured faculty

pros: Penn is a great place to work! You have access to exciting research opportunities and the ability to work with amazing people. West Philadelphia is diverse community of many different cultural and ethic groups.
cons: Pay is not competitive. Most positions are grant funded which lends to a bit of long term uncertainty. Most employees have not received a raise in over 4 years, this is quite pathetic for a world class health system. Penn should reward and retain great employees

pros: The people who work in higher education are great, they seem to be all intelligent and supportive of others interested in going into higher education. The hours and benefits are great too.
cons: As of majority of higher education, systems are set and very difficult to change. This makes it more challenging to accomplish things at times.

pros: Perelman School of Medicine is of the best institutions for biomedical research. Stellar faculty, top-notch ground-breaking research opportunities, and numerous resources provided to graduate students, postdocs, and employees (employees also get great benefits). Its a privilege to be part of an amazing community.
cons: Typical academic lifestyle-- constant fear of running out of grant money, and research funds, but if one is part of an established lab (there are many to choose from here), then it is less of a concern.

review_title: OK place to work as postdoc.
pros: Good people to work with, overall good environment to work.
cons: Almost no benefits.  They cover healthcare, but their starting salaries are a bit low (following NIH minima), they provide nothing else in terms of benefits.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Bala Cynwyd, PA
pros: The team work and management support is phenomenal in Home Care. We all share one common goal, the well being of our patients. The benefits are great and they strive to keep pay above average. Scheduling is flexible and there is always opportunity for advancement throughout Penn Medicine. Communication is key!
cons: Management "actively listening" to staff's feedback of those actually working in the field/floor.

pros: They offer a flexible schedule and the job is fairly easy. In addition, you sometimes meet celebrities when they have events or key speakers.
cons: This is a temporary position, however, they'll let you work there for however long you want. Because its a temporary position, you can not go over 20 hours per week.

review_title: Hard to grow as a mid to senior-level professional
pros: Excellent benefits, interesting work, great location and facilities. A growing organization with a rich history. The people are smart and capable.
cons: Penn does not provide any upward mobility for mid-level to senior-level professionals. THis is a common problem across the board at the University level.

pros: Penn is a good name brand in academia to forward your career. Average to above average inter-lab collaboration. Active postdoctoral group that promotes networking and funds travel.
cons: Postdoc pay is low for the hours you are expected to put in, but that's the case everywhere. The campus "neighborhood" where medicine labs are located has an industrial feeling and offers few places to escape to when writing or not at the bench.

pros: Work life balance with family values, people are friendly and nice. I feel very proud very time I tell people that I work for Penn.
cons: Once you are in your position grade, it is difficult to be reclassed, so please check out all the position grades before you apply.

pros: State of the art equipment,  a lot of scientific resources, fostering environment for scientific educations
cons: Post docs make NIH mins; lab choice is extremely important because there is no university support system to ensure post-docs are getting published successfully. Predocs have committees that have a say about projects students take to ensure they will publish in timely manner.

pros: Great to place full of smart people. They want to do great things and have the resources to do it.
cons: I do not think there are many cons. They realized I had potential and promoted me through the ranks. Learning the systemic operations of Penn will prepare you for any career in higher education.

pros: It's very convenient to live in Philadelphia, there are many different stores around Upenn. You can buy lunch from food trucks in the campus. Many job opportunities in upenn. Beautiful campus in the middle of a city. Philly's a really culturally diverse place- and so many great restaurants.
cons: Winter is cold.  public security is not good. Especially In urban setting, things can go wrong and you have to be prepared for that.

pros: Benefits package, including retirement contributions, were great. I worked in a fantastic unit with a wonderful director as my mentor. Beautiful energetic environment.
cons: The indirects on your grants don't buy you the "overhead" that they are supposed to. Ridiculously slow track for appointment and promotion. I know it's Penn, but come on!

review_title: Great benefits, good people to work with..
pros: The time off and holidays given are excellent, the flextime is dependent on department and supervisor, but very flexible and accommodating.  Smart, considerate, accepting and hardworking people can be found in abundance
cons: Limited opportunity and growth, many people stay here for long periods making it difficult to progress in your career, more mentoring should be made available.

review_title: Ivy league with very old system
pros:
Name recognition is always a plus, 
UPenn has great resources if you know where to look
Great scientists
Several programs to improve the work place
cons: It is a big bureaucracy with a lot of red tape. Sometimes the system that the use to get things done is antiquated.

review_title: This is an excellent place to work.
pros:
The University of Pennsylvania is well respected across the nation.
The environment for research is excellent.
The benefits and pay are good.
The law school, medical school, undergraduate campus, and Childrens Hospital of Philadelphia are all within close proximity.
cons:
the commuting time can be long on public transportation (by bus or train)
the parking is limited and relatively expensive

pros: You get good benefits, somewhat of job security depending upon what department you are in, nice employee assistance programs and ok discounts on certain things.
cons: They work you for little pay if you are not someone of importance, directors and higher ups are qualified on paper but not in experience.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I was very well supported by my advisor and all of my research experience was highly relevant to my areas of study. It was a great opportunity to be engaged in research while also doing coursework.
cons: The only cons that come to mind involve differences between compensation packages at different schools. My particular school did not offer much conference funding and offered one year less than most others.

pros: The University of Pennsylvania has very talented individuals, with a strong and expanding infrastructure for basic and translational research. Many opportunities for exciting exits.
cons: The pay is low and benefits are just alright, compared to what one can make in industry. Incentives, ie grant funding and notoriety for high impact results (which may not be reproducible), for researchers are misaligned in a way that minimizes real world impact for the vast majority of employees.

job_title: Research Project Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Excellent place of employment. Easily accessible with public transportation.  Benefit package and educational benefit package outstanding.  Versatile atmosphere to work in.
cons: Currently in a research position, that will run out of funding, would love to stay within the present position, but unlikely.

pros: great work environment, very helpful advisors. Did not feel stupid for not knowing what to do sometimes; people were very understanding.
cons: I really have no complaints,  I was given so much autonomy and was flown out of the country to present at a conference.

review_title: Review of Career Service at University of Pennsylvania
pros: The people around you were very friendly and they were very understanding as well. They go out of their to help you when you need assistance.
cons: I have nothing bad to say about Career Services. Everyone their was fantastic and they understood that we were students.

pros: One of the best universities for graduate students in the country; a generous package. Treatment of graduate students generally great, but depends department to department.
cons: University working to improve its protocol for lodging/handling complaints when you cannot rely on your department chair to do so, and this need for improvement is a complaint amongst students.

review_title: Great benefits, good place to work
pros: great benefits, opportunities for advancement, faculty and staff in general are great people to work and interact with. Good place to work.
cons: location, pay is only so so, political, takes forever to get things accomplished because of the many layers and decentralization

review_title: A Relaxed Personal Training Environment Less Focused on Sales Than Big-Name Gyms
pros: No need to meet difficult or high-pressure sales quotas. Flexible schedule (provided the clients' schedules are flexible as well). Free membership to a very good fitness facility.
cons: Work and income is dependent on client availability. Students have a poor long-term retention rate as clients due to graduations/transfers. No benefits offered as a part-time employee, and full-time positions do not exist for personal trainers.

pros:
Loved the team that I worked with during my tenure
Campus atmosphere is an absolute delight
Great benefits and flexibility
Work culture was fantastic
Work was intellectually challenging and rewarding
cons:
Some disorganization
Job stability was less than comfortable as my position was funding-contingent
Salary is not the strong suit of these positions. Working here is great for other reasons.

review_title: I love my job, and the opportunity that is given to me at the Smilow Research Center is second to none!
pros: The facilities at UPenn present a great opportunity, with friendly staff that are always willing to help and guide you through the path of knowledge!
cons: If you are inexperienced and new to the area, it is definitely hard to get adjusted. However, once you’re fully acclimated to your position, you’ll love the work!

pros: Great paid  vacation, can wfh regularly
cons: Senior management is completely unqualified for their positions. Especially the CIO Tom Murphy. He's destroyed what once was a friendly place to work at. He's probably destroying the place to get severance. Most people south title Director or higher at ISC AIS would not be able to find a similar job anywhere else, they're completely incompetent. The "strategies" they come up with are ridiculous and an obstacle to getting the work done. They also don't listen to what the actual people with expertise have to say since they're arrogant and clueless

pros: There was a high level of institutional support from the department. The stipend was competitive. Also, very collegial attitude among the students.
cons: The funding is being cut back across the board and this adversely affected the department. However, this is a problem around the country.

pros:
- Use the tuition + other benefits, you get access to most of the university
- Laid-back academic environment
- City campus
cons:
- decent pay for the work
- rigid career structure; no prospect for advancement outside the central bureaucracies. The people who stay at the university do so by transferring between departments and job positions.

review_title: Very positive and rewarding for me.
pros: Easy hours. Very Good pay. The candy bowl is always full. You can do school work while you do work.
cons: I have to get up early every day. You don't always know how to fix every problem. But none of this should stop you.

job_title: Assistant Director of Donor Relations in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The university of Pennsylvania is committed to a high level of education and professionalism within its staff both as teachers, administrators and professionals
cons: As with any large institution, red tape can always be an issue when trying to do things in new ways

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The University of Pennsylvania has many world-class researchers, which is heavily-weighted reason a graduate student would choose one school over another.
cons: Like any school, the professors at UPenn have specialties that may or may not overlap with a given graduate student's particular interests.

pros: Great location and close to home. Worked in my field of study assisting students pursuing higher education. This was a good organization to prepare students.
cons: Pay was no comparative to the industry. It was too low. Manager needed assistance - would often offend students and staff and then act like nothing happened.

pros: Fantastic research environment, good teaching environment.  Obviously depends on where you "land", but there are more seminars, research activities, and resources than you would have time for... Health benefits are decent.
cons: I currently get paid the minimum for postdoc with my experience (pay structure available online). Again depending on where you land, there may or may not be support for research / teaching: You'd have to actively search for it.

job_title: Associate Director of Research in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Pay and benefits are competitive, and there are plenty of perks especially for people who are interested in the intellectual and cultural resources that a top-tier university has to offer.
cons: It's a big institution, so patience is sometimes required for administrative issues, but it's really not that bad. I've heard it's difficult to advance, but I haven't asked for a raise or promotion yet, so I can't speak from personal experience.

review_title: Good place to get experience or benefits.
pros: The benefits, especially tuition benefits are very good.  Good 403b match up to 5% and up to 24 vacation days with 5 years of service.
cons: Salaries are not competitive with industry.  The daycare needs of the employees are not easily or affordably met.

pros:
Easy work
Flexible work hours
Job security
Very friendly coworkers
cons:
Not an environment that encourages progress and good work
No incentive to perform better, go anywhere or accomplish much
Few opportunities for growth

pros: Great work environment that manages to offer challenges, opportunities and rewards in perfect balance. Leadership is focused, communicative. Peers are wonderful, bright, supportive.
cons: PONDEROUSLY large organization. Can seem overwhelming at times. Best to study up as much as possible, tour the campus, learn everything you can about the school, regardless of whether you'll ever touch anything outside your office.

review_title: Highly political and frustrating work environment.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The first year is like college all over again.  Take some difficult classes, teach a little, and get paid a salary.
cons: Very long hours and extremely low pay.  Little freedom in course of study after adviser is chosen, which is not exactly how the experience is advertised.

pros: Unlimited journal and database access.  Working at the university allows you to have access to an extremely large number of journals and databases that would otherwise cost tens of thousands of dollars to subscribe to.
cons: Poor pay, large bureacracy.  The university pays very poorly and has an enormous number of administrative staff that are wholly worthless and do next to nothing.

review_title: My overall experience here is okay, but I think that the salary for employees could be a little better.
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: They will reimburse your money for school, like most jobs do. Also, the benefits are good and they take pride in making sure the employees are satisfied.
cons: There aren't really any cons of working here, but I can say now that trauma has been added to the hospital some days can be very busy.

pros: I am doing part-time research assistant, at Dept. of Computer and Information Science, school of engineering and applied science, PRECISE center
cons: tuition is expensive. philadelphia some times is cold. but to day is warm. summer is hot, not a good place to live

job_title: Research Specialist B in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Work with brightest minds in the industry, cutting edge projects, pushing thresholds.  Intriniscally pleasing work.
cons: Hard, arduous hours of work with little chance for quick advancement.  Minimal wage increases and unorganized work flow.  Need better benefits to offset lower compensation.

pros: The professors at Penn are really wonderful, generally very accommodating, and allow you to work on a more flexible schedule. This is particularly important when you have a class schedule to work around.
cons: Compensation is on an hourly basis and generally ranges from $10-$15. It's better than minimum wage, but there's room for improvement. These positions are often temporary and can change very quickly, as can be expected with research

pros: With some effort and ambition, you can become a very important member of the SEAS community, and have a lasting tangible impact on the education of those who follow in your footsteps. It can help develop your professional skills to lead, while also giving back to the community.
cons: Can be hard to juggle working hours while also at school.

pros: Plenty of opportunities for advancement, great education benefit, smart workforce, inspiring institution. Beautiful urban campus. Best President ever.
cons: Glacial change—often by committee—can be frustrating. This is not a place that fires "bad fit" employees, but invests in them to make them better fits. Again, frustrating if you're not the "bad fit." Nearly impossible to create one University among 18 incredibly different schools and centers.

review_title: Job was ok. Management was horrible.
pros: I enjoyed the job, the physicians I supported were great. Benefits were ok and my coworkers were nice.
cons: Supervisor was horrible! Micromanaging,  manipulative, conniving. Policies were made up to suit her needs, she intimidated her staff to get them to do what she wanted. She tried to turn us against one another with likes, so that we would only trust her. It wasn't worth the pay.

review_title: Great place to work with great benefits
job_title: Research Specialist B in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Benefits include tuition reimbursement, 5% match on 401K, great healthcare coverage.
cons: Insanely hard to get a promotion here - easier to leave current position within a lab to apply to another lab for a "promotion" than it is to get a promotion within your current position.

job_title: Associate Director (Student Services) in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
excellent benefits - retirement, great health insurance, vacation, holidays, tuition remission. 
accessibility to some of the best minds, good room for growth
respect for administrative professionals
cons:
culture of royalty among faculty
poor raises, no bonuses
parking on campus is terrible
difficult to be promoted/receive meaningful raises without changing jobs entirely

pros: Great benefits. Relaxed atmosphere. Pleasant management. Excellent work/life balance. Flexible schedule. Very nice area of the city to come to for work daily. Many opportunities for training and personal development.
cons: Salaries are a bit lower than what you would get in a similar role at a for-profit company/organization. The pace is slow. Takes a good bit of time to get projects going and completed.

review_title: Great Benefits, Experience Depends on Department
pros: excellent benefits; opportunities for advancement or at least lateral moves within the organization; fair HR practices; great place to work for networking; overall a good place to work
cons: compensation did not seem fair within my department (i was making more than a person who had been there 20+ years in the same position). staff morale was low, but seemed to be better in other departments.

job_title: Administrative Assistant A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Close to home.  People generally want to help.
cons: Expectations and work load is too much for a part time position.  Hard to get a position here if you have not worked at a University elsewhere.  Everything is "decentralized" with all of the headaches associated with that (and boy they are proud of that).

review_title: Great university, opportunities to continue learning
pros:
Vibrant campus
Employees can join student-run groups, such as the Penn Biotech Group
Opportunity to audit classes
Great Careers Services
Philadelphia: great restaurants, fun bars, walking distance between Center City and University City
cons:
Some labs/departments are past their 'best before' date
Don't trust reputations, seek previous lab members' advice for candid opinions
Loosing funding in some areas
Large organization, bureaucracy
Lack of support for postdocs, although there is a Biomedical Postdocs Program

review_title: Unlimited potential but bogged down by politics
pros: money, resources, and support to put ideas into action
cons: people are political and play favorites.  meaning often times the best projects don't get green-lighted in favor of superiors' pet projects.  but then superiors never get blamed for their pet projects the blame ends up with someone who probably had a better idea.

pros: Great environment, fairly flexible, no budget concerns, able to try new things within reason, GREAT physician support
cons: Odd hours, Department in flux, too many cooks in the kitchen from the top down, Micromanaging

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Nice city, and nice university. A lot of famous scientists across all disciplines. A lot of opportunities to collaborate.
cons: The benefits are just average level. The technical support department is not that efficient. The university is not very safe because of the urban location.

pros:
Ivy League Education
Strong Alumni Network
High growth potential
World-class academics
Strong, pre-professional culture with plenty of opportunities to grow
Vibrant background city
cons:
High volume and intense workload
Herd mentality into Finance, Consulting, and Computer Science
Dining plans are rather inadequate for the thousands we spend per semester.

review_title: Great teaching and research institution, but low pay
pros: UPenn is an amazing institution with world-class research, medicine and teaching. Good benefits.
cons: Low pay in many staff positions, and many in supervisory roles lack management skills and do not treat employees well.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: There is a lot of diversity at UPenn, they really make an effort to make people feel comfortable.  Also, there are a lot of professional development programs, and activities for postdocs.
cons: A lot of the PIs don't have funding, and there is a low tenure rate.  This causes a lot of labs to move to other universities in the middle of research.

pros: I spent twelve years at Penn Presbyterian and I the best part of that institution was that it was a teaching hospital.  I've learned so much and have to credit them for giving me the education, the knowledge and excellence of being successful in the healthcare profession
cons: Not enough hours in the day to help all the patients that need services

pros: Good benefits, decent pay. Many opportunities to move into different positions and different departments.
cons: Work culture somewhat cold, sanitized, where people can't be real with each other. There was a firm hierarchy that did not seem transparent and did not allow for employee input.

review_title: Very Good for my growth while also a student.
pros: Very Good place to work with growth opportunities, good leadership, friendly atmosphere. bosses are helpful and want you to move ahead, possible internship helps.
cons: Area is cold for living and cost of living is high at times. since working for school would like possible housing options to be available.

pros: Great mentor who constantly went to bat for me
cons:
Lack of vision from department chairman preoccupied with his own ego.
10% loss of grant funds to overhead, and another 10% would have been lost if I worked more then 20 hours week.
Despite exceptional performance, absolutely no guarantee I would have received full time employment

review_title: Great place to work and learn
job_title: Research Specialist A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great opportunity to get my hands wet and learn firsthand about academic research. I was given more responsibility than a lab technician and worked in a positive, challenging research lab. I learned how to think independently and contribute to scientific research.
cons: The hours are long and the pay is low for a starting Research Specialist.

review_title: Stable supportive work environment, but every takes long time to change nor much room for moving forward.
pros: supportive community. Tuition for continue education.
cons: under pay, hard to transition to higher level and pay. Pay increase is none or less than 2.5% per year.

pros:
Many opportunities to participate in clinical studies and collaborate with clinical scientists. Excellent for learning about the clinical side of the biomedical research.
Substantial tuition assistance is available for full-time staff.
Benefit coverage is great.
cons: Not easy to find opportunities to work on technically-focused research. Most are driven by the medical problems and the application of techniques. May not be an ideal environment for training in basic engineering.

pros: working at the front desk of a dorm is one of the easiest ways to make friends, get homework done, and get some customer service experience all while getting paid
cons: it depends on the timing of your shift, but you can sometimes expect to not be able to leave the desk at all during the entire shift. especially in the evenings, it gets very busy

pros: Great work/life balance, excellent benefits; great facilities; people are excellent to work with; free tuition for your kids; great energy on campus.
cons: Parking is expensive; commute can be long depending on where you live; take a while to get hired- process long

job_title: Clinical Research Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Personal/career growth for employees. Option to take classes and pursue a degree at a highly ranked institution. Great health benefits for all employees.
cons: No major negatives, there is a slight disconnect between PIs and staff but that is on a  case by case basis.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Research 1, Ivy League, Impressive Reputation. Penn can open many doors for future opportunities.
cons: Reputation alone isn't enough. More substance is needed. Considering a career outside of academia? Shhhhhh! Don't tell anyone!

review_title: I really enjoyed my life at Penn
pros: You have a lot of opportunities to get involved in the diverse cultures at Penn. Many of its schools are highly-ranked, including PennMed, Wharton and Law school. Also you'll enjoy it a lot if you are a city type person.
cons: The neighborhood is not the safest among the top universities, although they provide almost 24 hour school bus and shuttles.

pros: Working at Penn while conducting my studies there was phenomenal. I got the opportunity to experience different branches of my area of study that I wouldn't have otherwise gotten
cons: I honestly can't find anything negative about my time at Penn. The only complain I could find is the bureaucratic style of administration, but given the size of the institution this is rather common.

pros: Supportive culture. The instructors are helpful as well as the staffs. Students are understanding. Add value to resume. Great experiences for improving presentation skills.
cons: The job is very time demanding. Students are extremely sensitive on grading. Plus, the amount of grading is enormous. In my case, we had four mid-terms and a final for a class of 120 students with only two teaching assistants.

pros: Unmatched at any other university. They offer tuition reimbursement for children at any school, not just Penn, and also for spouses at Penn.
cons: Only negative is you have to pay taxes on your own tuition reimbursement but I believe that is federal law

pros:
Great working and learning environment
Get to work on challenging projects
Designing lab activities and teaching other students clears up a lot of concepts.
cons:
A lot of time consuming work.
Work load peaks during mid terms and finals, so it becomes difficult to balance your work with assignments and studying.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Family like working environment and always exciting projects. Going on 8 years here and despite cons haven’t wanted to leave
cons: Salary isn’t great. Options for promotions don’t come often and you need to fight for raises. Academia doesn’t ever pay great

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Excellent connections and networking opportunities. As a PhD student who was looking to transition to a high tier industry job after graduation, I have found these opportunities to be excellent.

Although the pay doesn’t compare to industry of tenure track professor jobs, the stipend is quite good for a PhD program.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy, but this is to be expected of academia.

pros: Many opportunities for collaborations and resources available to perform cutting edge research. The location of the university also poises it nicely as a hub for meetings.
cons: Unfortunately, as with any academic research community, there are very few opportunities for long-term career opportunities. Also, the compensation for research staff is tantamount to slavery. The lack of continuing education support is also disappointing.

pros:
Ability to do homework while on the job
Friendly staff
Work location that is close to where I live
Flexibility in setting up initial work schedule
cons: Since my overall school schedule is pretty intense, it would be optimal to have more flexibility in changing my hours on a week to week basis. However, I acknowledge that this is an expectation that is pretty unrealistic.

review_title: A good place to do research
pros: Penn is in a good location in the city.  Penn has devoted a lot of money and resources into building new state of the art research facilities.  Collaboration between labs is easy and encouraged.  Lots of special seminars and symposiums throughout the year
cons: Research lab experience is highly dependent on quailty of managerial skills of lab head.

job_title: Research Specialist A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The university has a large amount of resources. It also is very prestigious and can advance your chances of getting into graduate or medical school.
cons: Low salary, each lab differs dramatically in culture, lack of overall coherence and cooperation between labs

review_title: Great place to work, hard place to get promoted!
pros: The University is a wonderful setting with great benefits.  The opportunity for advance is great at the mid-level.
cons: Hard to be promoted to Director level.  Low pay scale for internal candidates.

pros:
One Receives an Ivy League Education
Strong Alumni Network
World-class academics
Opportunities for professional growth and development
Vibrant background city of Philadelphia
cons:
High workload
High volume and intensity of coursework
Herd mentality into finance, consulting, and computer science
Dining plans do not offer food of adequate quality

pros: Very nice colleagues. Interesting project. A good start point if you plan to stay on research track. Most of the mentor I met here are awesome.
cons: Stressful sometimes. There is no clear dead line for my project. But basically you will need to maintain a pretty good plan.

review_title: An excellent employer with outstanding benefits.
pros:
• Up to 24 days paid vacation per yer plus holidays
• 1 sick day earned per month
• Tuition assistance for employees, employee spouses, and children
• Up to 5% contribution-matching 401k
• Employee recognition events for every 5 years of service
cons:
• Most positions are on-site so commuting can be difficult.
• Advancement can become limited as upper positions are rarely vacated.

review_title: A stimulating challenge full of warmth.
pros: library and peer resources are abundant, especially with the resources of the best universities in the U.S.
cons: Penn's location is not particularly ideal in terms of living standards, as it is on the edge of Philadelphia proper, and scattered instances of armed robbery can be disconcerting.

pros: students and faculty are great - wonderful environment for collaboration
cons: Administration are totally disconnected from faculty. Corporate culture - leadership act like the entire University is here to serve the administrators, not the other way around.

pros: Great place to work in terms of work life balance. You even get a week off between Christmas and New Year! Great benefits, work from home options, room for advancement.
cons: Management is terrible. A lot of mediocre managers who don't manage poor performers or managers who micro-manage and are burned out from working here too long. Lots of resistance to change.

review_title: Great career boost for student applying to entry level positions
pros: Innovative projects to work on and close proximity to all colleges and schools added a tremendous boost to my projects.
cons: All the time-consuming work fall on you and have to get it finished on time.  Unsatisfied with the pay for the hours of work put in.

pros: Great opportunity to connect with students and see them learn the concepts as you teach the material to them. The satisfaction of the students when it finally clicks is a reward in itself.
cons: Hours may be peculiar (late at night) or on weekends. Just a matter of scheduling and when the classes are scheduled for the semester.

pros:
A complete and well-designed schedule for fundamental theory and practice.
A number of alumni are working in top level movie making and gaming industry.
cons:
The research side of this program is not very strong.
If you are looking forward a professional life, unfortunately, the courses in this program covered a number of topics but none of them would go very deep.

review_title: Sub-par pay, advancement opportunities non-existent.  Not your typical academic learning environment.
pros: Willing to flex schedule, tuition benefits
cons: Harsh work environment, upper management does not invest in younger employees, cheap, pay well below competition (even among other academic institutions).  Management is strict, yet vague, and unforgiving with deadlines and expectations.  Closer to a sweatshop, grindstone sort of environment than an open, engaging academic learning environment.

pros: Produce great publications and has numerous resources for conducting a wide range of experiments.  Core staff are extremely helpful. Prepares you for a career in academia
cons: Postdoctoral salary is minimal pay for the expertise they require and except 60+ hours of work per week.  Most postdoc appointments last for 5+ yrs before a position in academia can be found.

pros: Stimulating environment, knowledgeable people, try to improve experience of patients and medical students (i work in Medical school), top-of-the-line expertise, fosters collaboration
cons: Older colleagues may be stuck on certain ways, relatively slow to adapt to new ideas, bureaucracy like in most big institutions

pros: stable, clean, and you get to work with good people who are dedicated to their patients and their jobs. Patient care jobs can be very rewarding
cons: sometimes administration doesn't understand how it is to actually work every day with limited resources and not enough staff. And charging for parking for people who work on Christmas Day just seems sad

job_title: Research Specialist B in Philadelphia, PA
pros: All of the benefits are great for both a single person and for families.  Penn is a safe and pleasant environment with various places to eat. I found the people to be professional and friendly to work with and research interesting.
cons: I can't find much to complaint about this work place.

review_title: Good job, boss has no time though
pros: immense flexibility, decision-making power, independence
cons: boss has little time and will not check in - you must actively ask for a meeting in order to get feedback, not a career job - much more of a stepping stone

job_title: Patient Service Associate in Cherry Hill, NJ
pros: Great benefits for myself and my family at a low cost. Great PTO package to start. Convenient location, very proud to be a part of the Penn Health System.
cons: No room for growth that the Cherry Hill facility, only options to advance are to go over the bridge. The hourly pay is just fair at best considering the work load.

review_title: Very good opportunity as a transitional period between college graduation and higher education or advanced career.
job_title: Research Specialist A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Because it is an academic environment, people are always willing to teach you. It's a great environment to learn new techniques and broaden knowledge and skillsets.
cons: University salary does not compare to living expenses of Philadelphia, no promotions or bonuses like in private companies.

pros: It looks very good on a resume. My boss is lenient and for the most part it is independent work. Work is assigned and one is expected to come up with helpful insight.
cons: One of the cons is that working as a work study student doesnt pay that much, and we're only given limited amount of assignments to complete.

pros: Work hands on with students and improve your own teaching skills. Excellent pay for being an undergrad student. Professors are great and experience people to work with.
cons: Balancing your other coursework, especially around midterms and finals, can be challenging. But if you have good time management, you should have no problem! Great place to be working at!

review_title: Disorganized yet rigorous and helpful (Chemistry PhD student)
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Everyone is brilliant and helpful when help is sought.
cons: Hours are very long, pay is very little, and job prospects are not even presented to the students during orientation or any time for that matter.

pros: Small lab with very attentive principal investigator and lab manager. Good environment that makes it easy for learning and gaining professional skills while being a student.
cons: The pay is low, but that is expected still being a student. It's hard to balance school and research.

review_title: An amazing institute for graduate research work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
cons: The only con I can think about for a Ph.D. graduate student is this place makes you wanna stay longer and sometimes you might miss the opportunity to move on to your next career.

review_title: A lot of Pros but very stressful cons
pros:
Give feedback to employees on their current performance and make organization expectations clear.
Identify strengths and weaknesses of individual employees and teams as a whole.
Help team members develop as employees and people.
Allocate promotions or pay raises appropriately.
Explain individual and organizational goals.
Use it as a goal setting opportunity.
cons: Pretentious professors and no real work-life balance available

review_title: PennCAP Office of UPenn, Best Place of First Employmennt
pros: Good place to learn office dynamics (secretarial, clerical, reception, small meeting set-up), great pay, very flexible, kind staff
cons: Unchallenging (you will spend most of your time doing nothing at all, which leaves having developed a very limited skill set)

pros: In a great and affordable city, Upenn provides an excellent atmosphere to do incredible work. While the hours expected is dependent on the respective boss, your hard work and accomplishments are rewarded.
cons: Some of the professors think that they are the cream of the crop when really they are barely pushing the top 10-15%.

review_title: University has great benefits, but some departments are shockingly dysfunctional
pros: University has great benefits, its a beautiful campus and a great place to work.
cons: My particular department (Business Services) has a terrible culture and most people are actively job searching.

pros: I believe that Penn is an exceptional place to work in Information Technology! There are so many opportunities at the university and the diversity and knowledge of the workforce here is very unique.
cons: Sometimes the direction and culture of the organization are in conflict. I fully expect and hope that these mis-alignments change for the better.

review_title: Great place to work! Brilliant people, wonderful environment.
pros: You learn alot and there are many other opportunities given you to gain experiences needed to help you be successful. It's a collaborative environment where your managers are very supportive.
cons: It's can be hard to be a graduate student while working. You have to be able to work on balancing both.

review_title: This was an excellent place to work.
pros: Fun environment, but fast paced. It was challenging but the people there will work with you if you have problems.
cons: Personally, it was a long drive to get to work. Some areas were very hot and did not have air conditioning. Other than that it was great!

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Thriving research environment. Flexible and friendly. Good mentoring system. Good pool of students and postdocs.
cons: Depends too much on federal grant support. Quality of research can be low, because researchers are under a lot of pressure to publish and get funding.

pros: Fill out free time. Easy job to handle. Some kind of relaxation between stressful sessions. Flexible and pleasant to work.
cons: Sometimes boring. Patience and carefulness absolutely needed. During final week or busy time, it is not wise to go on working.

review_title: Penn is amazing, I have moved up so quickly in such as short time. You learn, and do something new everyday.
job_title: Research Specialist A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Love the school, work experience is great! Benefits are amazing!
cons: The only downfall to this place is lack of pay, for work done.

pros: Large employer, great health insurance, good wages, we'll known in the community. Good experience is gained there
cons: Inequality, most managers are promoted only because of length of their employment not because of knowledge or credentials

pros: Tuition benefits are great. Those with kids wont have a tuition bill.
cons: Management can play games and not be fair in paying you based on your contributions. Youth oriented. Volume of work between two people can be so vast it borders on exploitation.

pros: Great benefits like tuition and health care, flexible schedule, wonderful coworkers sometimes intellectually challenging, the work can be very niche and unique
cons: Rigid bureaucracy, no promotion available, cyclical nature of work which goes between high stress and profound boredom, the niche nature of the work can sometimes lead to hours of searching for obscure tech

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Smart minds, great research, many graduate students and post-docs, big name PIs
cons: Use and abuse graduate students in some labs, false sense of future job security for graduate students and post-docs in the academic field

review_title: Diplomacy is key to maintain reputation
pros: Domestically, Penn is great. Competitive salary, nice campus environment, room for rapid advancement if you show initiative.
cons: Under their grants mechanisms, they opt to fund in-house upgrades in lieu of supporting foreign research sustainability. It causes some diplomatic friction.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: There is a strong Postdoctoral program with a lot of workshops and enrichment activities.  They really do try to get the postdocs to become active in the university.
cons: Postdocs are expected to work long hours.  During orientation, they put up a slide saying that we should expect to work 75 hours per week!

review_title: Research experience is very valuable, but compensation is low
job_title: Research Specialist A in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The department I worked in was very supportive, including the faculty. Very collaborative. Mentorship was a priority. I was given a few other part-time internal job offers while there.
cons: Low salary for a city. Facilities were not always the most new and clean. Some disorganization (nothing terrible) among administration.

review_title: Big academic that is generally friendly and committed to learning and research.
pros: Cutting edge research, interaction with bright students and top-notch academics. Great medical center. Philadelphia a fun and affordable city to live in with lots of activities and downtown core that is not overwhelming.
cons: Leadership focuses on results, rather than people. Bureaucracy can be very thick at times.

pros: Health benefits are good; research support and collaborations are excellent; lateral move is easy
cons: parking is a huge problem, administrative staff while helpful are so overloaded that most work got delegated to labs doing self-reporting

pros: University of Pennsylvania is an Ivy league university in a historical and pleasant city. It has top research resources in the world. Living expense is moderate, comparing to other major cities.
cons: As many big cities, there are some safety issues, but the university police patrol all night and even walk together with you back home.

pros: Every day is different. Stimulating to be working with and among such brilliant young people. Great location and amenities.
cons: Limited upward growth, but much intra-university mobility. Sometimes disconnect between schools and programs, sometimes communication is challenging in such a large institution.

pros: Amazing colleagues, great work-life balance, competitive benefits including retirement contributions, the opportunity to take courses and pursue advanced degrees, and getting to work with students who impress me every day.
cons: Large and decentralized - it can be difficult to identify the proper office/role to answer a question or assist with a project.

job_title: Research Specialist B in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Healthcare, up to 5% matching retirement contributions, tuition reimbursement, tuition assistance for your children when they go to college. Research facilities at the School of Medicine are state of the art and enjoyable to work in.
cons: Low salaries, but that is endemic to academia in general. Convoluted HR process for getting raises/promotions.

job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Working At Pennsylvania hospital has allowed me to grow as a nurse they provide their staff with Support, teamwork, chances for professional development, they Also are supportive of furthering education.
cons: At times I felt like my department could be political...truly there Are not many cons working for penn medicine they Are the Beat of the best

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Very affordable city to be on a phd stipend for four years. Good funding and benefits.
cons: Could be making more in real world, but phd is worth it in the long term.

pros: Excellent benefits, flexibility. work culture, and the people are great. Campus is historic and beautiful with many perks available to staff. University has a high cache.
cons: The pay is not as high as you would see in the private sector, although the health benefits are better than most private sector offerings.

pros: Biomedical Postdoc Program is excellent and provides useful educational and training activities, all of the schools (med school, dental school, business school, etc) is located on the same campus, labs are fairly collaborative
cons: You can only be a postdoc for 5 years, benefits and pay are so-so, my department HR is slow

pros: Great working environment, employee support and benefits are off the chain! Training and development are great...
cons: Too much bureaucracy & politics , slows effectiveness and makes career movement within the organization much more difficult than it has to be

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator B in Phila, PA
pros: The work environment and my coworkers are great. Close to public transportation. Management is very good listeners and down to earth.
cons: There is a lack in structure regarding on the job training. There is no official training, however, you have 4 months of probation.

review_title: Good for early career, not a lot of room for growth in research.
job_title: Senior Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Decent benefits package, including tuition and nutrition counseling. Lots of amenities on campus, some aren't cheap though. Always a lot of free food around.
cons: Salary is low and there is a lot of bureaucracy. Too much red tape and things take forever to do.

pros: The people are fantastic, the work is necessary and admirable and making the world a better place, and the work-life balance is great and very manageable.
cons: It was a slightly slow work pace and didn't pay incredibly, though the fact that it paid an undergraduate summer intern at all as a nonprofit is commendable.

pros: Excitement! Cutting edge! This is where immunothearpy happens, immunogene therapy with commercial spin-outs. Patients get what they deserve; my lab works on generating cutting edge therapies, democratizing this, bringing within reach for "the average Joe".
